Als Trainingsgast präsentierten die Sechziger allerdings zunächst einen Defensivmann.
Der 30 Jahre alten Hrvoje Cale war zuletzt in Belgien aktiv und stand früher auch schon beim VfL Wolfsburg unter Vertrag.
Der Kroate habe derzeit "die Möglichkeit, sein Können unter Beweis zu stellen".
Torjäger Rubin Okotie kann nach seiner Gehirnerschütterung kommende Woche wieder ins Mannschaftstraining zurückkehren.
Schon an Donnerstag soll der österreichische Nationalspieler ins Lauftraining einsteigen.
Okotie hatte sich in der Partie bei Fortuna Düsseldorf (0:3) bei einem heftigen Zusammenprall am Kopf verletzt.
Entgegen ersten Befürchtungen blieb er aber ohne eine schwerwiegende Blessur.
Keine Diät-Frucht - Mangos enthalten viel Zucker
Mangos sind exotisch und saftig-süß.
Wer aber auf seine schlanke Linie achten will, dem wird von ihnen oft eher abgeraten.
Denn Mangos enthalten relativ viel Zucker - vor allem Saccharose.
Gesund sind die exotischen Früchte trotzdem: In ihnen stecken B-Vitamine sowie die Vitamine E und C. Vor allem enthalten Mangos aber viel Vitamin A und dessen Vorstufe Beta-Karotin.
Wer die Früchte isst, unterstützt somit Sehkraft, Immunsystem und Stoffwechselprozesse im Körper.
Beim Kauf sollten Mangos nicht zu weich oder zu fest sein und angenehm riechen.
Die Schalenfarbe allein sagt nichts darüber aus, wie reif die Frucht ist - also können auch grüne Mangos sehr lecker schmecken.
Sie sollten bei Zimmertemperatur lagern und innerhalb weniger Tage verzehrt werden.
Dann schmecken sie natürlich pur oder in süßen Speisen.
Eine Mango gibt aber auch herzhaften Gerichten eine besondere Note.
Sie mildert den leicht bitteren Geschmack mancher Blattsalate wie Chicoree und Radiccio.
Und ein Mangochutney passt gut zu Fisch, Geflügel, Lamm und Wild.
Der US-Paketdienst UPS stellt für das Weihnachtsgeschäft in den USA wieder bis zu 95000 Aushilfen ein.
Das Unternehmen habe mit der Rekrutierung von Saisonarbeitern bereits begonnen, teilte UPS am Dienstag mit.
Vor allem Fahrer werden gesucht.
Bereits im vergangenen Jahr hatte UPS seine Belegschaft für die Feiertagssaison um 95000 Aushilfen aufgestockt.
Angesichts des boomenden Online-Geschäfts treffen UPS und sein Konkurrent FedEx seit vergangenem Jahr früher Vorkehrungen, um für das Weihnachtsgeschäft gewappnet zu sein.
2013 hatten verspätete Lieferungen den Paketdiensten harsche Kritik eingebracht.
Zuerst Föhnsturm, dann markante Kaltfront
In der kommenden Nacht bricht in den Tälern der Alpennordseite der Föhn durch, wie Meteoschweiz am Dienstag mitteilte.
Am Mittwoch und in der Nacht zum Donnerstag bläst der Föhn teilweise mit Sturmstärke durch die Föhntäler.
Nach Föhnende am Donnerstagmorgen überquert uns eine markante Kaltfront, die kräftige Regenfälle, Windböen und einen Temperaturrückgang bringt.
Wie MeteoNews in einer Mitteilung schreibt, liegt die Schweiz derzeit auf der Vorderseite eines umfangreichen Tiefdruckgebietes über den Britischen Inseln in einer kräftigen Südwestströmung.
Auf der Alpennordseite bricht in der Nacht zum Mittwoch der Föhn durch die Täler.
In der Folge bläst der Föhn bis Donnerstagmorgen in den Föhntälern mit Böen von 60 bis 100 km/h, vereinzelt und speziell im Urnerland teilweise auch mit über 100 km/h.
Der Föhn kann stellenweise bis ins angrenzende Mittelland vordringen, und auf den Bergen sind sogar Orkanböen von über 120 km/h möglich.
Während im Norden am Mittwoch stürmischer Föhn für sommerliche Temperaturen von 23 bis 27 Grad sorgt, beginnt sich die Feuchtigkeit am Alpensüdhang zu stauen.
Hier setzt Regen ein, der bis Donnerstagabend anhält.

In Summe muss südlich der Alpen in den nächsten 48 Stunden mit teilweise über 100 Liter Regen pro Quadratmeter gerechnet werden, dies nachdem in den letzten Tagen schon grosse Regenmengen gefallen sind.
Am Donnerstagmorgen geht dem Föhn die Luft aus, in der Folge rollt eine Kaltfront mit kräftigem, teilweise gewittrig durchsetztem Regen von West nach Ost über die Schweiz.
Zusammen mit der Kaltfront frischt der Wind stark bis stürmisch auf, und die Temperaturen gehen deutlich zurück.
Die folgenden Tage präsentieren sich im Norden herbstlich mit 15 bis 20 Grad, im Süden hingegen wird es am Wochenende sonniger und wärmer mit bis zu 25 Grad.
Rom hat jetzt einen Martin-Luther-Platz
Knapp 500 Jahre nach der Reformation gibt es in Rom jetzt einen Martin-Luther-Platz.
In Anwesenheit von Stadtpräsident Ignazio Marino wurde am Mittwoch ein bisher namenloser Platz im Park auf dem Oppio-Hügel auf den Namen des deutschen Reformators getauft.
Auf der "Piazza Martin Lutero" wird er jetzt als "Deutscher Theologe der Reformation" gewürdigt.
Der Park liegt mitten im alten Rom gleich neben dem Kolosseum.
Die Namensgebung war von der Arbeitsgemeinschaft der evangelischen Kirchen in Rom beantragt worden.

Jens-Martin Kruse, Pfarrer der Evangelisch-Lutherischen Gemeinde in Rom, erinnerte am Mittwoch daran, dass die Protestanten in der Stadt der Päpste über Jahrhunderte als Minderheit oft nur im Verborgenen ihren Glauben leben konnten.
Mit dem Platz werde in symbolischer Weise sichtbar, dass ihre Tradition des christlichen Glaubens in Rom willkommen sei.
Martin Luther (1483-1546) hielt sich als junger Augustinermönch um die Jahreswende 1510/11 einige Monate in Rom auf.
Er empfand die Stadt damals als verkommenes Sündenbabel.
Seine negativen Eindrücke dürften ihn nach Ansicht von Historikern in seinem späteren Kampf gegen Rom bestärkt haben.
Luther hatte dann mit seinen Thesen gegen den Ablasshandel die Spaltung der abendländischen Kirche eingeleitet.
Hammer Künstler investierte drei Jahre in die persönliche Interpretation der Bibel
Jesus mit der (vergoldeten) Dornenkrone ist eines der Hauptwerke, die Otmar Alt für seine Bibel gemalt hat.
Klaus Altepost hat die Einführung geschrieben und Bibeltexte aktualisiert.
Am Anfang war das Wort?
Nein, nicht bei der Otmar-Alt-Bibel, die jetzt mit prächtigen Bildern erschienen ist.
Am Anfang war das Bild für Otmar Alt, der in 150 Motiven seine ganz persönlichen Interpretationen biblischer Geschichten auf Papier und Leinwand formuliert hat.
Seine "Sprache" mit bunten Farben und fantasievollen Formen hat der 75-Jährige erhalten - was aber keineswegs gleichbedeutend ist mit "lustigen" Bildern.
Im Gegenteil: Den jeweiligen Themen angepasst, kann das durchaus recht düster wirken.
Rund drei Jahre hat Otmar Alt an seinem Bibel-Projekt gearbeitet, für das er eine subjektiv-künstlerische Auswahl aus den vielen Themenbereichen des "Buches aller Bücher" getroffen hat.
Entstanden sind Zyklen, die sich Themen wie Kreuzweg, Plagen, Gebote oder Vaterunser widmen.
Damit hat er spontan gleich mehrere Partner fasziniert: Das gilt für den Luther-Verlag mit seiner theologischen Ausrichtung ebenso wie für den Kettler-Verlag mit seinem Schwerpunkt auf Kunstbüchern.
Und da ist vor allem der Autor Klaus Altepost, der sich auf Grundlage der Malerei mit den jeweiligen Bibelstellen auseinandergesetzt hat.
Er hat die von Otmar Alt ausgewählten Bibelstellen interpretiert und so ins Heute, in aktuelle Zusammenhänge "übersetzt".
Diese Texte sind wie verbale Spiegel von Alts Malerei.
Eingebettet sind sie zwischen dem Original-Bibelzitat von Martin Luther und jeweils einem Satz des Künstlers, der hier seine ganz persönlichen Gedanken zur jeweiligen Situation formuliert.
Der Schmuckeinband hat goldene Lettern.
So erlaubt der 75-Jährige gleich doppelt einen tiefen Einblick in seine Seele, seine Emotionen.
Das ist ein hohes Maß an Intimität.

Emotionen waren letztlich überhaupt Auslöser für das Bibel-Projekt: Otmar Alt, 1940 in Wernigerode geboren und in Berlin aufgewachsen, kommt aus einer Familie, die dem strengen protestantischen Herrnhuter-Orden angehörte.
"Da geschah die Erziehung schon mal mit dem Rohrstock", erinnert sich Otmar Alt.
"Ich habe versucht, das aufzuarbeiten, um mich vielleicht auch wieder mit dem Herrn Vater zu vertragen".
Sein zweites Anliegen sei, der Kunst in schnelllebiger Zeit wieder zu mehr Stellenwert zu verhelfen: "Die Wahrnehmung von Bildwelten ist heute von Reklame geprägt, und die ist laut.
Symbolik wird da verdrängt.
Künstler haben eine andere Lust und Wonne, Dinge zu zeigen.
Bilder haben immer etwas Geheimnisvolles und sind nicht dekorativ.
"In dieser Hinsicht bin ich ein Dinosaurier".
Otmar Alt möchte, dass sich die Betrachter in die Bilder "hineinfallen" lassen, sie auf sich wirken lassen, entdecken und spüren, welche Kraft sie haben: "Das Bild sucht sich sein Gegenüber".

Klaus Altepost gestand am Dienstag bei der Präsentation der Otmar-Alt-Bibel in der Otmar-Alt-Stiftung, "schon immer" ein Liebhaber von Otmar Alts Kunst gewesen zu sein: "Ich mag, wie er mit seinen Bildern Leben begreift".
Alt habe nicht darauf geachtet, die Bibel vollständig zu erfassen, sondern die für ihn wichtigen, auch geheimnisvollen Themen ausgewählt.
"Das war keine Zusammenarbeit auf Augenhöhe", sagt Altepost: "Hier geht es um die Bilder, der Text erläutert lediglich". Entstanden sei eine Bilder-Bibel.
Für Hans Möhler vom Luther-Verlag ist dieses Werk eine Einladung, "sein Leben zu vertiefen und Freiheit zu finden".
Otmar Alts Bilder sprechen für Möhler sowohl die (biblische) Sprache der Liebe als auch die der Verantwortung.
Ein Teil der Originale - Papier- und Leinwandbilder - wird erstmals in einer Ausstellung präsentiert, die am 15. November in der Otmar-Alt-Stiftung eröffnet wird.
Baubeginn für BMX-Bahn naht

Pläne gemacht, Platz gefunden, Unternehmen beauftragt, Erdhügel für einen Rundkurs modelliert: Ein Jahr später war fast alles fertig - doch noch vor der offiziellen Eröffnung der BMX-Bahn war damit schon wieder Schluss.
Versäumnisse in Politik und Verwaltung sorgten für Verdruss, vor allem bei den Anwohnern, die die Bahn nicht dulden wollten.
Also Hügel abgeschoben, neuen Platz gesucht - nun mit förmlicher Planung und Antrag auf Baugenehmigung.
Die Genehmigung werde im Oktober eingehen, konnte die Erste Gemeinderätin Sabine Mosebach-Bock jetzt im Kinder- und Jugendausschuss mitteilen.
"Ich hoffe, dass dieses Jahr noch Sichtbares passiert", sagte sie.
Es solle dann ohne "weitere Gedenkpause" mit den Arbeiten beim ehemaligen Hallenbad begonnen werden.
DFB intensiviert Engagement für Flüchtlinge
Der DFB weitet sein Engagement für Flüchtlinge bis 2019 aus, die Bundesliga setzt am Wochenende ein deutliches Zeichen.
Der Fußball reagiert auf die sich zuspitzende Lage in Deutschland und sichert der Politik seine Hilfe bei der Bewältigung der anstehenden Probleme zu.
"Ich halte das für die größte Herausforderung unseres Landes seit der Wiedervereinigung."
"Da kann im Prinzip niemand sagen, das geht mich nichts an, ich habe damit nichts zu tun."
"Das muss jeden einzelnen interessieren, dieses Thema in den Griff zu kriegen", sagte DFB-Chef Wolfgang Niersbach.
Beim jährlichen Treffen mit Bundeskanzlerin Angela Merkel am 23. September in Berlin will er die Flüchtlingssituation in Deutschland intensiv erörtern.
"Ich bin nächsten Mittwoch im Kanzleramt und treffe dort die Staatsministerin Frau Özoğuz und die Kanzlerin."
"Da wird das Thema sicher eine zentrale Rolle spielen", kündigte er an.
Der Fußball könne und wolle helfen.
Die entscheidenden Weichen muss aber die Politik stellen.
Der Deutsche Fußball-Bund hat deshalb seine Flüchtlingsinitiative "1:0 für ein Willkommen" um vier Jahre ausgeweitet.
"Über die Egidius-Braun-Stiftung haben wir sichergestellt, dass dieses Programm bis 2019 weiterläuft", erklärte Niersbach am Rande der UEFA-Tagung in St. Julian's/Malta.
Auch einige Bundesligisten unterstützen dieses Programm.

Bereits an diesem Wochenende setzen die 36 Profivereine ein deutliches Zeichen, wenn sie auf dem linken Trikotärmel statt des sonst üblichen Sponsorenlogos (Hermes) den Aufdruck "Wir helfen - #refugeeswelcome" tragen werden.

"Wir wollen damit auch deutlich machen, dass alle helfen sollen, wo und wie sie nur können", sagte Leverkusens Sportchef Rudi Völler der "Bild"-Zeitung (Dienstag) und bezeichnete das Vorhaben als "Selbstverständlichkeit".
"Das Flüchtlings-Drama geht jeden an, keiner darf wegsehen."

"Wir Fußball-Bundesligisten können, nein, wir müssen unsere Strahlkraft, unseren Einfluss und unsere Möglichkeiten nutzen, um den vielen Flüchtlingen, die schon so unglaublich gelitten haben, zu helfen", sagte Hertha-Manager Michael Preetz.
Hoffenheims Geschäftsführer Peter Rettig sprach von einem "prominenten Zeichen der Liga".
Zum EM-Qualifikationsspiel gegen Ungarn an diesem Freitag lädt die Nationalmannschaft der Frauen 100 Flüchtlinge nach Halle/Saale ein.
Niersbach bezeichnete die Unterstützung von Flüchtlingen als "ein großes Gemeinschaftswerk deutscher Fußball".
Dass alle 36 Lizenzvereine in ihren Orten eigene Projekte gestartet hätten, sei großartig.
Genauso großartig ist, dass kleine und kleinste Vereine da aktiv sind.
Die Botschaft "1:0 für ein Willkommen", die wir ausgegeben haben, wird im Fußball gelebt.
"Das ist von enormer Bedeutung", sagte er.
In diesem und dem nächsten Jahr stellt der Verband gemeinsam mit der DFB-Auswahl und der Bundesregierung jeweils 300 000 Euro für die Integration von Flüchtlingen zur Verfügung.
"Die Vereine haben die ganze Summe für 2015 auch schon abgerufen", berichtete Niersbach.
Berichte: SAP-Vorstandschef verliert bei Unfall ein Auge
Der Vorstandschef von Europas größtem Software-Konzern, Bill McDermott, hat mehreren Berichten zufolge durch einen Sturz Anfang Juli das linke Auge verloren.

Bei dem Unfall auf der Treppe im Haus seines Bruders in den USA sei er nach Mitternacht auf ein Wasserglas gefallen, das er in der linken Hand getragen habe, berichte die "Wirtschaftswoche" am Mittwoch.
"Er ist fast verblutet, war ohnmächtig, hat sich dann raus geschleppt auf die Straße - das hat er uns so erzählt letzte Woche", zitiert die "WiWo" SAP-Mitbegründer Hasso Plattner.
McDermott könne aber seiner Arbeit nachgehen.
"Anfang Oktober treffen wir uns vor der Aufsichtsratssitzung in Walldorf", sagte Plattner.
Der 54 Jahre alte Manager sei bei dem Treffen dabei und "voll arbeitsfähig".
McDermott kündigte in einem Interview mit der "Süddeutschen Zeitung" (Donnerstagsausgabe) an, er werde im Oktober wieder nach Deutschland kommen und weiter den Softwarekonzern führen.
"Ich bin voll für SAP da, voll in meinem Job."
"Selbstverständlich stand ich die ganze Zeit in regelmäßigem Kontakt mit dem Aufsichtsrat und dessen Vorsitzenden Hasso Plattner", sagte McDermott der "SZ".
McDermott pendelt üblicherweise zwischen Deutschland und den USA, seit dem Sommer aber war er nicht mehr in der deutschen SAP-Zentrale in Walldorf.
Ihm sei es wichtig, mit einer solch persönlichen Geschichte an die Öffentlichkeit zu gehen, sagte der Manager der "SZ": "Jedem kann so etwas passieren."
"Wichtig ist, wieder aufzustehen, wenn man hingefallen ist."

Fußball: BVB ohne Reus gegen Krasnodar: Weidenfeller im Tor
Bei Borussia Dortmund haben sich alle Hoffnungen auf ein Comeback von Marco Reus im ersten Gruppenspiel der Europa League endgültig zerschlagen.
Der Nationalspieler wird dem Tabellenführer der Fußball-Bundesliga auch im Duell mit dem FK Krasnodar am Donnerstag (19.00 Uhr/Sky) fehlen.
"Wir können auf ihn leider nicht zurückgreifen", sagte Thomas Tuchel am Mittwoch.
Ob Reus am Sonntag im Bundesliga-Topspiel gegen Leverkusen wieder dabei sein wird, ließ der BVB-Coach offen: "Wir rechnen mit einer Rückkehr von ihm ins Training am Freitag".
Angesichts der hohen Belastung seiner Profis wird Tuchel seine Stammelf nicht nur auf der Reus-Position verändern.
So kündigte er einen Wechsel auf der Torhüterposition an.
Deshalb nimmt Roman Weidenfeller den Platz von Stammkeeper Roman Bürki ein.
"Er trainiert auf einem absoluten Top-Niveau", lobte der Fußball-Lehrer den Weltmeister.
Ob Weidenfeller in Zukunft in allen Europa-League-Spielen zum Einsatz kommt, ließ Tuchel jedoch offen.
Mit hoher Wahrscheinlichkeit wird er auch die zweite Partie bestreiten.

Die forsche Aussage von Mitspieler Reus, dass der Finaleinzug für den BVB in der Europa League das Ziel sein müsse, hält Mittelfeldspieler Julian Weigl für nachvollziehbar: "Damit liegt Marco nicht so falsch."

Roboterautos: Regierung will Vorreiterrolle für Deutschland
Deutschland soll nach dem Willen der Bundesregierung beim Wandel des Autos technologischer Vorreiter sein.

Das Bundeskabinett beschloss am Mittwoch ein Strategiepapier aus dem Haus von Verkehrsminister Alexander Dobrindt (CSU), das unter anderem Investitionen in den Ausbau digitaler Infrastruktur vorsieht.
Dobrindt sprach am Mittwoch in Frankfurt am Rande der Automesse IAA von einem "neuen Mobilitäts-Zeitalter".
Das automatisierte und vernetzte Fahren werde die Verkehrssicherheit erhöhen und für weniger Staus sorgen, sagte Dobrindt.
Er will das Thema auch mit seinen Amtskollegen aus den G7-Staaten besprechen, die auf der IAA auch mit Vertretern der Industrie zusammenkommen.
Das Strategiepapier des Verkehrsministeriums betont unter anderem die Bedeutung des mobilen Breitband-Ausbaus und eines zügigen Umstiegs auf digitalen Hörfunk.
Zur Erprobung neuer Technik entsteht derzeit eine Teststrecke auf der Autobahn 9 in Bayern.
Damit dem Fahrer "keine zusätzlichen Haftungsrisiken aufgebürdet werden", will die Bundesregierung die rechtlichen Rahmenbedingungen "überprüfen und, wo nötig, an die neuen Entwicklungen anpassen".
So will sich Deutschland etwa international dafür einsetzen, dass die zulässige Höchstgeschwindigkeit für selbstfahrende Autos von 10 auf 130 Stundenkilometer angehoben wird.
Die Bundesregierung will sich außerdem für eine Änderung des Wiener Übereinkommens einsetzen, das bislang nur den Menschen als Fahrer vorsieht.
Beim automatisierten Fahren übernimmt in zunehmendem Maße das Auto die Führung, der Fahrer wird mehr und mehr zum Passagier.
Die Technologie basiert vor allem auf Sensoren und Kameras, die die Umgebung erfassen und die Daten in Sekundenschnelle verarbeiten.
Nach einer vom Wirtschaftsministerium vorgelegten Studie wird hochautomatisiertes Fahren auf Autobahnen bis 2020 technisch möglich sein.
Trotzdem seien fahrerlose Fahrzeuge auf öffentlichen Straßen "erst weit nach 2020 zu erwarten".
Die Wertschöpfung im Bereich der Fahrerassistenzsysteme und der hochautomatisierten Fahrfunktionen am Standort Deutschland schätzen die Autoren der Studie für 2025 auf rund 8,4 Milliarden Euro.
"Die digitale Vernetzung des Pkws kann zur mehr Sicherheit und Effizienz im Straßenverkehr führen", sagte der SPD-Verkehrspolitiker Sören Bartol.
Die Frage der Haftung bei Unfällen und die Sicherheit der persönlichen Daten der Fahrer müsse aber eindeutig geklärt sein.
Noch sehen die Deutschen selbstfahrende Autos allerdings skeptisch - viel mehr als Franzosen oder Amerikaner.

Eine am Mittwoch auf der AA vorgelegte Umfrage des Forsa-Instituts im Auftrag der Prüforganisation Dekra kommt zu dem Ergebnis, dass nur acht Prozent der Deutschen glauben, dass sich autonom fahrende Autos in den kommenden zehn Jahren durchsetzen werden, 32 Prozent rechnen erst in 20 Jahren damit, 31 Prozent glauben überhaupt nicht daran.
In Frankreich rechnen 21 Prozent der Befragten bis 2025 mit autonom fahrenden Autos, in den USA 33 Prozent.
Ohnehin sind die Autofahrer in Deutschland noch nicht bereit, sich komplett auf ein selbstfahrendes Fahrzeug zu verlassen.
Nach einer Erhebung des Digitalverbands Bitkom würden nur sieben Prozent zustimmen, die Kontrolle während der gesamten Fahrt auf allen Straßen abzugeben.
Auf der Autobahn könnten sich das im fließenden Verkehr immerhin 15 Prozent vorstellen, im Stau 45 Prozent.
Gut jeder Vierte würde dem Auto die Kontrolle unter keinen Umständen überlassen.

Es ist eine Mischung aus ganz großer Modenschau und einem Wachsfiguren-Gruselkabinett: Der Designer Jean Paul Gaultier (63) hat am Mittwoch in München eine Ausstellung über sein Werk vorgestellt.
Die Höhepunkte: Schaufensterpuppen, die dank Videoprojektionen erschreckend menschlich aussehen.
Sie tragen die spektakulären Kreationen des französischen Designers, der unter anderem mit Madonnas Bühnenoutfits zum großen Star der Modeszene wurde - und damit, dass er Männer in Röcke steckte.
"Ich kann heute nicht mehr sagen, dass ich das Enfant terrible der Haute Couture bin, weil ich weißes Haar habe."
"Früher war es gebleicht, inzwischen ist es echt", sagte Gaultier.

Für die Besucher der Ausstellung "From The Sidewalk To The Catwalk" (Vom Bürgersteig auf den Laufsteg), die vom 18. September an in der Kunsthalle der Hypo-Kulturstiftung zu sehen ist, ist es ein Glück, dass der Modeschöpfer seine anfangs ablehnende Haltung zu einer Schau über seine Person geändert hat.
Eigentlich sei er dagegen gewesen, denn: "Für mich klang eine Ausstellung ein bisschen nach Tod", sagte er.
Wenn man stirbt, kommt man ins Museum.
Die beeindruckende Sammlung hatte vorher schon im kanadischen Montreal und in Paris Station gemacht.
"Es geht um so viel mehr als nur schöne Kleider", sagte der Direktor der Kunsthalle, Roger Diederen.
Es gehe um Toleranz, Akzeptanz und die Vision einer offenen Gesellschaft.
Die Exponate geben einen Einblick in das kaum noch zu überblickende Werk des Mannes, der Modegeschichte geschrieben hat, ohne jemals eine Ausbildung absolviert zu haben.

Chronologisch ist die Schau nicht aufgebaut, aber sie ist ein hervorragend choreographiertes Gesamtkunstwerk, für das viel Aufwand betrieben wurde: Um die Puppen zu frisieren, wurde zum Beispiel eigens ein Stylist engagiert.
14 Tonnen Material haben die Macher nach Angaben des Kurators Thierry-Maxime Loriot nach München gekarrt.
Kurz vor dem Start des Oktoberfestes war noch ein besonderes Schmankerl dabei: ein Lederhosen-Outfit mit Korsett.
Heidi meets Madonna.
Er habe sich immer für starke Frauen interessiert ("Frauen sind schlauer als Männer") und für Menschen, die ein bisschen anders sind, sagte Gaultier.
Auch Gaultiers alter Teddy ist in der Ausstellung zu sehen.
Er steht für die ersten, zaghaften modischen Gehversuche des Designers.

Schmuck statt Gardine - Plauener Spitze als Mode-Nische
Früher ging es an den langen Stickmaschinen in und um Plauen darum, Meter zu machen.
Die bestickten Stoffe und Spitzen entstanden in großer Menge für Kunden, die sie beispielsweise zu Decken und Gardinen weiterverarbeiteten.
Das allein funktioniert heute nicht mehr, erklärt Andreas Reinhardt, Geschäftsführer der Modespitze Plauen.
Stattdessen ist die Mode wieder wichtig.
In den Anfangszeiten der Plauener Spitze spielte Mode eine größere Rolle, wurde dann durch die Heimtextilindustrie verdrängt - und wird jetzt als Nische wiederentdeckt.
Reinhardt nennt einige Beispiele: Spitze in Schmuck, bei Accessoires wie Taschen und bei regionalen Trachten.
Überhaupt bilde die sogenannte Vintage-Mode, die sich an vergangene Stilepochen anlehnt, ein zunehmendes Auftragspotential.
Wer in der Textilbranche in Deutschland keine Nischen bedient, ist nicht mehr am Markt.
Bei uns machen sie bereits die Hälfte aller Aufträge aus.
Modespitze Plauen ist zusammen mit neun weiteren Unternehmen Mitglied im Branchenverband Plauener Spitze und Stickereien.
Nur sie dürfen das geschützte Label tragen.
In den letzten 15 Jahren seien rund 80 Prozent des Umsatzes weggebrochen.
Private Fachgeschäfte und auch den Großhandel gibt es fast nicht mehr.
Unsere Produkte erreichen den Kunden auf diesem Wege kaum noch.
Die Massenware werde heutzutage im asiatischen Raum viel billiger hergestellt und fast ausschließlich über Ketten vertrieben.
Außerdem schwächle der Export, aktuell nach Russland und in die USA.
Genügend Gründe also für neue Wege.

Der Branchenverband versucht auch durch Umweltbewusstsein zu punkten, wie Cordula Bauer von der Stickperle in Falkenstein erklärt: "Seit diesem Jahr führen wir ein Qualitätssiegel, das zeigt, dass wir ökologisch und sozial verträglich produzieren".
Reinhardt ergänzt: "Das bezieht sich auch auf die verwendeten Materialien".
Diplomdesignerin Ute Schmidt lehrt an der Schneeberger Außenstelle der Westsächsischen Hochschule Zwickau - an der Fakultät für angewandte Kunst - und ist auf Stickereien und Spitzen spezialisiert.
Um der Konkurrenz aus dem asiatischen Raum etwas entgegenzusetzen, muss man hochwertige und innovative Produkte finden.
Das braucht Zeit und Mut.
Es entsteht ein Spannungsfeld zwischen den frischesten Ideen der Designer und den Betrieben, die vor allem wirtschaftlich denken müssen", sagt Schmidt.
Deshalb werde ein bestehendes Design oftmals nur leicht variiert, um einen Kundenstamm zu halten.
Vor einigen Jahren belebte Textildesignerin Kati Reuter die historische Schneeballspitze neu.
Dabei stickt die Maschine an einigen Stellen kleine Kügelchen.
Die Plauener Goldschmiedemeisterin Bianca Hallebach-Krauße ließ sich davon inspirieren: "Vorher konnte ich mit traditioneller Plauener Spitze nichts anfangen".
Jetzt verwendet sie die Schneeballspitze für ihren Schmuck.
In einem aufwendigen Verfahren prägt sie das Muster in Silber.
"Viele Menschen der Region identifizieren sich mit dem Thema Plauener Spitze - jung und alt", sagt Reuter.
Sie liefert auch in die USA, nach Australien und nach Finnland - vor allem an Kunden, deren Vorfahren in Plauen und Umgebung gelebt haben und die ein Erinnerungsstück möchten.
Damit sehe ich meinen Schmuck als modernen Botschafter der Plauener Spitze.

Xi drängt darauf, die Wirtschaft breiter für die Welt zu öffnen
Die Wirtschaft muss sich breiter nach außen hin öffnen, um Wachstum zu fördern, sagte Präsident Xi Jinping am Dienstag einer Gruppe, die mit der Lenkung der Reform beauftragt wurde.

"China sollte sich dafür einsetzen, ausländische Investitionen und Know-how anzulocken und die Strategien für Geschäftsgründungen zu verbessern", sagte er in einer Ansprache bei der 16. Sitzung der Zentralen Führungsgruppe für die Vertiefung einer umfassenden Reform.
Neugründungen zu fördern und Reformen voranzutreiben wird neuen Schwung und Vitalität herbeiführen und neuen Platz für das Wirtschaftswachstum bieten, sagte Xi.

Die Führungsgruppe hat eine Reihe von Richtlinien verabschiedet, einschließlich einer Negativliste zur Regelung des Marktzugangs, Entspannung der Grenzkontrollen-Politik, Förderung der Staatsbetriebe (SOE), privates Kapital aufzunehmen, und Überholung des Einwohner-Meldesystems.
Nach dem Statement wird eine Negativliste erstellt, die Sektoren und Unternehmen identifiziert, die für Investitionen nicht in Frage kommen.
Das System wird nach und nach getestet und durch Testprogramme verbessert.

Die Initiative ist von Bedeutung, da sie dem Markt eine größere Rolle bei der Zuteilung von Ressourcen zuweist, ein rechtsstaatliches Geschäftsumfeld gewährleistet und den Markt offener gestaltet, sagte das Statement.
Die Regierung wird auch Kontrollen über die an die Unternehmen übertragenen Befugnisse lockern und dafür sorgen, dass Unternehmen entscheiden, wie sie ihre Geschäfte führen.

Das Statement sagte auch, dass China Grenzgebieten erlauben wird, neue Modelle der grenzüberschreitenden Wirtschaftskooperation und neue Mechanismen zur Förderung des regionalen Wachstums zu erkunden.
Im Rahmen eines Angebots, staatlich kontrollierte Sektoren zu öffnen, werden weitere Bereiche für private Investitionen geöffnet.

"Die Regierung wird ihre Politik gegenüber ausländischen Investitionen nicht ändern und wird die rechtmäßigen Interessen von fremdfinanzierten Unternehmen schützen und bessere Dienstleistungen für sie erbringen", sagte das Statement.

Darüber hinaus wird es für Ausländer einfacher gemacht, eine dauerhafte Aufenthaltserlaubnis oder die "Green Card" zu beantragen, indem die Anforderungen optimiert und der Bewerbungsprozess erleichtert werden.
Das Recht der Anwälte zu garantieren, ihre Tätigkeit auszuüben, und professionelle Richter und Staatsanwälte einzusetzen, wurde ebenfalls bei einer Sitzung erörtert.
An der Sitzung nahmen auch Premier Li Keqiang und wichtige Führer wie Liu Yunshan und Zhang Gaoli teil, wie in einer nach dem Treffen veröffentlichten Erklärung gemeldet wurde.
EU will Quecksilber-Grenzwert in Raubfischen verdoppeln
Die Europäische Kommission will die Grenzwerte für Quecksilber in großen Raubfischen verdoppeln und den Verbrauchern damit eine deutlich höhere Dosis des Nervengifts zumuten.

Die Verbraucherorganisation Foodwatch, der ein entsprechendes Arbeitspapier der EU vorliegt, kritisierte die Pläne scharf: "Risiken und Nebenwirkungen verfehlter Industrie- und Umweltpolitik werden mit voller Wucht an Schwangere und Kleinkinder weitergereicht", erklärte Matthias Wolfschmidt von Foodwatch.

Wolfschmidt zufolge sollen die Grenzwerte des Nervengiftes für große Fische am Ende der Nahrungskette wie etwa Hai- oder Schwertfisch aus "wirtschaftspolitischen Gründen" von einem auf zwei Milligramm Quecksilber je Kilogramm Fisch angehoben werden.
Große Raubfische seien aber schon heute so stark mit Quecksilber belastet, dass auf Grundlage der noch geltenden Grenzwerte etwa 50 Prozent der Fänge nicht verkauft werden dürfen.
Nach Verdoppelung der Grenzwerte wären dann nur noch 14,5 Prozent unverkäuflich.
Im Gegenzug für dieses Lockerung will die EU laut Foodwatch die Grenzwerte bei anderen Fischen von derzeit 0,5 Milligramm auf 0,1 Milligramm Quecksilber pro Kilogramm verschärfen.
Foodwatch bezeichnete dies aber als "Trick", weil kleinere Friedfische, wie etwa Karpfen meist so niedrig belastet sind, dass sie die geplanten Höchstwerte bereits heute einhalten.
Die Absenkung bei Kleinfisch sei deshalb "ein perfides Ablenkungsmanöver, das allein der Wirtschaft hilft", erklärte Wolfschmidt.
Quecksilber ist ein für den Menschen hochgiftiges Schwermetall, das sich über die Nahrungskette vor allem in Raubfischen stark anreichert.
Die Bundesregierung warnt deshalb davor, dass "bereits geringe Mengen besonders bei Ungeborenen Schädigungen des Nervensystems" verursachen können.
Das Bundesumweltministerium erklärt auf seiner Homepage im Hinblick auf die geltenden Höchstwerte aber, dass eine "gesundheitliche Gefährdung der Allgemeinbevölkerung" nicht zu erwarten sei.
Quecksilber gelangt vor allem durch die Kohleverbrennung in die Umwelt.

Die deutschen Kohlekraftwerke stoßen laut einer schriftlichen Auskunft des Bundesumweltministeriums an die Grünen-Bundestagsabgeordnete Annalena Baerbock mehr als sechs Tonnen Quecksilber im Jahr aus, zwei Drittel der in Deutschland emittierten Gesamtmenge.
Die Konzentration von Quecksilber in Fischen etwa in Elbe, Rhein und Donau sei "dauerhaft und flächendeckend überschritten", hatte der "Spiegel" im März aus dem Papier zitiert.
Im vergangenen Jahr zählten europaweite Warnungen vor Quecksilber in Fisch bereits zu den häufigsten gemeldeten Gesundheitsrisiken im EU-Warnsystem RASFF.
Foodwatch ruft Verbraucher zum Protest gegen die Pläne der EU auf unter: www.quecksilber-aktion.foodwatch.de

In a 911 call, Professor Shannon Lamb told police in a shaky voice that he had shot his girlfriend and that officers needed to come to his home.
Lamb said it was important to stress that his "sweet dog" was still alive and probably excited, and said the dead woman's family contacts could be found on the phone.

Inside the house, officers found the body of Amy Prentiss and a hand-written note scrawled on a white pad: "I'm so sorry, I wish I could take it back, I loved Amy, and she's the only woman who ever loved me." That's what the authorities said was written in the note, and the note was signed by Lamb.

There was no indication that Lamb, who taught two online courses for Delta State University in Cleveland, Mississippi, had already travelled 300 miles to the campus where, police say, he shot and killed a popular history professor, Ethan Schmidt, at the door of his office.
Delta State University Police Chief Lynn Buford said that university staff heard the shooting at 10:18 am.
He said Lamb made the fateful call sometime after that.
By the end of the day, there was another death: Lamm took his own life when police cornered him.
A day after the shooting at the university forced students and teachers to hide behind locked doors, authorities are still trying to piece together what motivated Lamb.
Details released by investigators at both ends of the state, as well as what students and staff who knew him said, helped to paint a picture of a talented but possibly difficult teacher.
Students said that they were looking forward to his lessons.
Police in Gautier, where Prentiss died, said he had no history of violence or a criminal record.
Schmidt himself had mentioned Lamb in a book he wrote, in which he discussed the "wonderful people" with whom he shared his academic life.
Both taught in the Department of Social Sciences and History, whose faculty comprised 17 members, and many students took courses from both.
At the same time, there were some tendencies towards problematic behaviour.
A student, Brandon Beavers, who praised Lamb, said he also seemed a bit excited and nervous, “as if something was wrong with him.”
Another student, Mikel Sykes, said that Lamm told him he had been dealing with stress towards the end of the 2014-15 academic year.
Lamb had previously asked for a leave of absence from Delta State University for health reasons, saying he had some kind of health issue.
This year, he taught only two online courses.
The latest changes in the university's employment policy meant that the PhD he had worked so hard to obtain would no longer guarantee him an automatic route to an assistant professorship.
University President William LaForge said he was not aware of any conflict between Lamb and Schmidt, but "obviously there was something in Mr Lamb's perception".
These are questions that Lamb can no longer answer.
After fleeing the campus, police later found Lamb's trail when he re-entered Mississippi from Arkansas.

Before he could be arrested, Lamb killed himself with a .38 caliber pistol in the backyard of a house about a mile south of his parent's home on the outskirts of Greenville, Mississippi, said Washington County Coroner Methel Johnson.
His car was still in the driveway.
It was not immediately clear why Lamm went to the house, but Johnson said she believed he knew the people who lived there.
Lamb grew up in the area.
Lamb started working at the university in 2009, which has 3,500 students in a town of about 12,000 people and taught geography and education.
He graduated in pedagogy in the spring.
One of Lamb's long-standing friends described him as intelligent, charismatic and funny.

She and her friends were in high school and he was the cool older guy who tried for years to teach her how to play the guitar.
He was a heartthrob back then.
All the girls would melt when he was around," said Hairston, now 40 and living in the Jackson suburb of Brandon.
Lamb and Prentiss were obviously together for some time.
In the 911 call Lamb said "I killed my wife", but there was no record of a marriage.
They had a dog named Lightning, who lived with them in the brick house that abuts a bayou in Gautier.
The police said the dog was all right.
Prentiss's ex husband, Shawn O'Steen, said they were divorced 15 years ago but remained friends and had a daughter who is now 19 years old.
"She was totally devastated," O'Steen said of his daughter.
She and her mother were absolutely best friends.
O'Steen said he had never met Lamb, but he had heard from his daughter Abigail that Lamb was interested in music and played blues.
Lamb met Prentiss when they were both performing at a summer fair three years ago.
Later they played a few gigs together.
O'Steen said that his daughter writes and sings her own music.
Prentiss was a nurse who worked online for various companies.

Mike Shaffer, a bartender and sometimes entertainment coordinator at The Julep Room, a dimly lit bar near Gautier, said he last saw Lamb and Prentiss the night of Sept. 5, shortly after Lamb finished his guitar and harmonica playing before a sparse audience.
There was no sign that anything was wrong.
"Just a happy couple" he said.
We were cleaning up and joking with each other.
I mean, they both had a good sense of humour.

Toys R Us plans to hire fewer workers for the Christmas season.

Toys R Us says it will not hire as many seasonal employees for the holiday season as it did last year, but the toy and baby products retailer says it will give current employees and seasonal workers a chance to work more hours.
The company said it plans to hire 40,000 people at stores and distribution centres across the country. Last Christmas season, it hired 45,000 workers.
Most of the jobs will be part-time jobs.

UN Secretary General Ban Ki-moon said his response to Russia's increased military support for Syria was: "There is no military solution" to the nearly five-year conflict, and more weapons would only worsen violence and misery for millions of people.
The UN chief has once again called on all parties, including the divided UN Security Council, to unite and support inclusive negotiations to find a political solution.

Ban told a news conference on Wednesday that he plans to meet the foreign ministers of the five permanent council members - the US, Russia, China, Britain and France - on the sidelines of the General Assembly ministerial session later this month to discuss the situation in Syria.
He regrets that the divisions within the Council and within the Syrian people and regional powers "make this situation intractable."
Ban urged the five permanent members to show the same unity and solidarity in dealing with the crisis in Syria that they have shown in reaching a nuclear deal with Iran.

But no matter how some Republicans try to pull Donald Trump down from the top ranks in polls, it hasn't worked so far.
Ten of the last 11 national polls showed Donald Trump leading by double digits, and some are starting to seriously wonder what it means for the real estate mogul's chances of securing the nomination.
Of course it is still early days in the election period.
No one is claiming that Trump is likely to win the Republican nomination.
Experts pointed out that at this time in 2011 Rick Perry's lead was given up to the rising Herman Cain, neither of whom won a single state in the nominating process.
And there are many reasons why he might struggle in a general election.
But outside groups like Jeb Bush's super PAC and the conservative economic group Club for Growth are now recognizing Trump's staying power and are starting to spend their dollars to bring him down.
Here are some current polling numbers that suggest the real estate mogul is more than just a passing fad:
Trump's popularity ratings have turned 180 degrees.
Shortly before Donald Trump announced his candidacy in mid-June, a Monmouth University poll showed that only two in ten Republicans viewed the real estate mogul positively.
By mid-July, it was 40%.
In early August it was 52%.
Now, six in 10 Republicans have a positive view of Donald Trump.
About three out of ten say they have a negative view.
And these numbers hold in early states.
A Quinnipiac Poll in Iowa last week found that 60% of Republicans have a favorable opinion of Trump.
Two-thirds of GOP voters would be happy with Trump as a candidate.
In a CNN/ORC survey last week, 67 percent of Republicans said they would be either "enthusiastic" or "satisfied" if Trump were nominated.
Only two in 10 say they would be "upset" if he were the candidate.
Only Ben Carson comes close to generating the same level of enthusiasm as Trump (43 percent say they are "enthusiastic" vs. 40 percent who say the same about Trump).
Next in terms of enthusiasm?
Marco Rubio with just 21 percent.
On the other hand, 47% of Republican voters say they would be "dissatisfied" or "angry" if Jeb Bush, the establishment favourite, became the nominee.
A majority of Republicans do not see Trump's temperament as a problem.

While Donald Trump has been widely criticised for his bombastic and insulting comments, 52 per cent of leaning Republican Irish voters think the real estate mogul has the right temperament to be president, according to ABC News/Washington Post on Monday.

The same number holds in the nation's first caucus state of Iowa, where 52 percent of Republicans think he has the personality to be a commander-in-chief, according to a Quinnipiac poll released last week.

Nevertheless, 44 percent think he does not have the personality to be effective in office, and almost six in 10 independents say his temperament is not suited to the White House, according to ABC/Post.
Republican voters are getting used to the idea.
When they put their thinking caps on, Republican voters consider Trump to be real.
When asked who is most likely to win the GOP nomination, four in 10 say Trump is the best bet, according to a CNN/ORC poll released last week.
That's a shift from the four in ten who favored Bush back at the end of July.
Full disclosure: GOP voters have not had the clearest crystal ball in the past.
At this point in the last cycle, four in ten Republicans thought Rick Perry would win the nomination, compared to just 28% for eventual candidate Mitt Romney.
Nevertheless, a large number of GOP voters see Trump's campaign as plausible.
Even if the Republicans rallied around another candidate, Trump would still beat almost anyone.
Some experts point out that the fragmented field is probably contributing to Trump's lead, while the anti-Trump support is spread diffusely across more than a dozen other candidates.
But a Monmouth University survey earlier this month showed that in a hypothetical head-to-head race between Trump and most other Republican candidates, Trump enjoys majority support.
He has a 13-point lead over Carly Fiorina, 14 points over Marco Rubio, 15 points over Walker, 19 points over Jeb Bush, and 33 points over Rand Paul, John Kasich and Chris Christie.
It's a neck-and-neck race with Ted Cruz.
The only candidate who beat him?
Ben Carson would top the businessman by 19 points in a hypothetical head-to-head race.
A narrow majority of Donald Trump's fans say they have made up their minds.
A new CBS/NYT poll released Tuesday shows that just over half of voters who support Trump say they have firmly decided to vote for him.
Of course, much can happen to change that, and no one can really say never to change their mind.
46% said they would keep the door open to switch to other candidates.
Nevertheless, Trump's strongest competition at the moment is another outsider, neurosurgeon Ben Carson, but voters who say they have made up their minds are twice as likely to support Trump.
Six out of 10 Republicans say they agree with Trump on immigration.
Since Donald Trump called Mexican immigrants "rapists" in a campaign speech two months ago, immigration has been a key issue in the public discourse of 2016.
Some are concerned that Trump's bombastic rhetoric will turn off key Hispanic voters and damage the party's rebranding efforts.
But according to a new ABC/Post poll released Monday, six in 10 Republicans say they agree with Trump on immigration.
So long as immigration remains in the spotlight, it seems so will Donald Trump.
Frustration with the government is rising to new heights.
Donald Trump and Ben Carson now account for nearly half of support among Republican voters, mainly because of their outsider status.
Six in 10 Republicans say in the new ABC News/Washington Post poll that they'd rather have a political outsider than someone with government experience.
And they are also angry at Washington.

A Des Moines Register/Bloomberg poll in Iowa two weeks ago showed that three out of four Iowa Republicans are frustrated with the Republicans in Congress, with 54 percent "dissatisfied" and 21 percent "hell-angry."

Smokers have a higher risk of losing their teeth.
Smoking not only harms the lungs but also the teeth, a long-term study in Potsdam suggests.
The good news: if you give up, the risk decreases rapidly.
Smokers have a significantly higher risk of losing their teeth early.
This is the conclusion of a long-term study by an international team of researchers, including several from the German Institute of Human Nutrition (DIfE) in Potsdam.
Compared with non-smokers, smokers had a 2.5 to 3.6 times higher risk of losing their teeth prematurely.
The scientists had observed more than 23,300 participants.
According to the DIfE, the main causes of tooth loss are tooth decay and gum inflammation.
Smoking is a risk factor for this periodontal disease, the authors emphasize.
The link between smoking and tooth loss is due to more frequent gum infections among smokers.
It is not clear whether smoking also increases the risk of tooth decay.
People who stop smoking could reduce their risk within a short time, the researchers write in the Journal of Dental Research.
It could take up to 10 years for the risk to return to that of non-smokers, said lead author Thomas Dietrich from the University of Birmingham.
"Smoking shortens life expectancy," said study leader Heiner Boeing from the DIfE. "We need to convince people not to smoke."
Not smoking is good for the lungs and blood vessels and, according to our knowledge, also leads to good dental health well into old age.
In Germany, 20% of the population aged 65 to 74 years old suffer from toothlessness, the DIfE reported.
Previous studies have already indicated that smoking increases the risk of early tooth loss.
The new long-term study supports the findings.

EU Commission proposes new court in dispute over TTIP
To defuse tensions over the proposed transatlantic free trade agreement, the EU Commission has proposed a comprehensive reform of the current arbitration system.
The controversial private arbitration mechanisms for disputes between corporations and states are to be replaced by a more transparent mechanism that will function more like a traditional court.
"We want to set up a system that citizens can trust," EU commissioner Cecilia Malmström said as she unveiled the proposals.
The Swede plans to put the proposal forward as a European negotiating position in trade talks with the US.
The German government announced its support.
TTIP is intended to create the world's largest free trade zone with 800 million people.
The reform proposals specifically envisage that both EU countries and the US would jointly appoint independent judges for a new investment court.
They are expected to come equally from the EU, the US and third countries.
A second instance is also planned for the first time.
It would allow appeals against verdicts.
Until now, the parties involved have agreed mutually on arbitrators, and there has been no possibility of appealing against their rulings.
In the debate over the past months, it has become clear that citizens do not trust the old ISDS system when it comes to fairness and justice, Malmström commented.
In the long run, it wants to work towards setting up an international investment court.
This could, for example, settle disputes between Chinese businesses and EU nations.
The investor-state dispute settlement system (ISDS), which is largely demanded by large corporations, is considered one of the main reasons for the strong resistance in Europe against TTIP.

Traditional arbitration tribunals have been criticised by opponents as a form of parallel justice system whereby corporations can claim compensation at the expense of taxpayers, overturn national laws or force down consumer or environmental standards.
Anti-TTIP organisations like Campact have described the EU Commission's proposals as insufficient.
Critics have pointed out that they would not apply to the already negotiated free trade agreement with Canada (Ceta).
German economy state secretary Matthias Machnig (SPD) described the plans as a big step forward.
The commission's proposal incorporates key points worked out by economy minister Sigmar Gabriel and other EU trade ministers in the spring.
The old system of private arbitration is off the table.
The French government also welcomed Malmström's plans.
BusinessEurope, the European business association, warned against limiting the ability of European business to take legal action by creating too many new rules.
This could disadvantage smaller and medium-sized enterprises, it was said.
It remained unclear on Wednesday when talks on the Transatlantic Trade and Investment Partnership (TTIP) could be completed.
Talks have been underway since mid-2013.
The issue of investor protection has not yet been discussed with the US.
A framework for the deal was originally expected to be in place by the end of this year.
This deadline is seen as no longer feasible.

Jeremy Corbyn's debut at Prime Minister's Questions
Since his election, Mr Corbyn's debut at Prime Minister's Questions has been eagerly anticipated.
The new Labour leader, Jeremy Corbyn, is expected to make his debut at Prime Minister's Questions and will face David Cameron for the first time.
Mr Corbyn will rise to ask his first of six pre-selected questions shortly after midday, with his performance likely to be closely scrutinised by both the media and Labour MPs.
He called for "less theatre and more facts" at this weekly event.
He also said he could skip some sessions to leave them to his colleagues.
The meeting will be the first parliamentary test for Mr Corbyn's leadership, following his appointment to the shadow cabinet and his speech to the TUC conference on Tuesday.

In the meantime, the Labour leader's decision to remain silent during the singing of the national anthem at a Battle of Britain memorial service on Tuesday has provoked criticism from a number of Tory MPs, and is the focus of several front page stories in the papers.
Mr Corbyn's decision not to sing the national anthem has drawn attention.
A spokesman for Mr Corbyn said he had stood "in respectful silence" and he had acknowledged the "heroism of the Royal Air Force in the Battle of Britain".

But a member of Mr Corbyn's shadow cabinet, Owen Smith, told the BBC Two Newsnight programme that he had advised the Labour leader to sing the national anthem, "irrespective" of his belief the monarchy should be abolished.

Nearly a dozen shadow ministers have refused to serve in Mr Corbyn's top team, citing differences over economics, defence and foreign policy, while less than one-sixth of the parliamentary party initially backed him as leader.
BBC political correspondent Robin Brant says political differences are stacking up within Labour too, following Mr Corbyn's comments on the party's position on Europe and on a cap on pay rises.
Mr Corbyn told the TUC conference that Labour would introduce changes to remove the whole concept of a cap altogether.
Hours later, shadow work and pensions minister Mr Smith said the party was "very clear" that it was only against the government's plans to lower the cap from £26,000 to £23,000.
Mr Corbyn will be the fifth Labour leader to face David Cameron across the dispatch box in Parliament in the last decade, since he became Tory leader.
The Labour leader, who has promised a different approach, says that he has "crowd-sourced" ideas for questions to Mr Cameron and has been given more than 30,000 suggestions.

The Islington North MP has said that Prime Minister's Questions is too confrontational and that he will avoid both "sparring" and "point-scoring" and instead focus on serious issues such as poverty, inequality, and the challenges facing young people.
Mr Corbyn has said that Angela Eagle, the shadow business secretary, will represent him when he cannot attend - for example if Mr Cameron is abroad.
He also raised the idea of letting other colleagues speak more often, and said he had spoken to Commons Speaker John Bercow about the issue.

When he became leader in 2005, Mr Cameron said he wanted to move away from "Punch and Judy" politics often associated with Prime Minister's Questions, but a few years later he admitted he had failed to do so.

As it was first televised in 1990, Prime Minister's Questions has been seen as the most important barometer of a leader and his government's standing in the House of Commons and his standing among his parliamentary colleagues, although critics have argued that it has become a caricature and needs far-reaching reform.

Metcash launches grassroots campaign to combat Aldi invasion
Metcash is attempting to protect IGA stores from an Aldi onslaught in South Australia and Western Australia.
Food wholesaler Metcash has launched a ground-up campaign to defend the market share of IGA retailers in South Australia and Western Australia ahead of a $700 million Aldi invasion.

As Aldi prepares to open two distribution centres and its first 120 stores in South Australia and Western Australia early next year, Metcash and IGA supermarkets are strengthening their relationships with local food suppliers and building the IGA brand through mainstream marketing and promotion via social media and events such as the Adelaide Show.

IGA retailers and suppliers are jumping on board, with brands like Dunsborough ice-cream maker Simmo giving out samples in IGA stores and store owners selling discounted tickets for the South Australian football league to loyal customers.
Metcash is expected to reveal further details of its defence strategy on 29 September when the food, liquor and hardware wholesaler holds its annual investor strategy day.

There's a lot at stake, with South Australia and Western Australia accounting for almost 30 per cent of Metcash's IGA stores and generating higher earnings margins than Metcash's IGA network in the eastern states.

Shoppers in South Australia and Western Australia are notoriously parochial and IGA retailers have much stronger market shares than in New South Wales, Victoria and Queensland - more than 30 per cent in South Australia and 24 per cent in Western Australia compared to around 14 per cent in the eastern states.

However, analysts such as Morgan Stanley believe that Aldi will take around five per cent of the grocery market in both countries 12 months after opening its first stores, and will take sales away from all existing players but primarily independent retailers.
According to a report released this week, analyst Tom Kierath from Morgan Stanley estimated IGA retailers could lose $360 million in sales a year and Metcash $250 million by the end of 2016.
This forecast is based on the assumption that Aldi will open 25 stores in SA and 30 in WA next year and generate sales of $500 million and $600 million in each market.
The loss of the food and grocery business and the volumes on Metcash’s high fixed cost base could cost Metcash about $13 million in earnings before interest and tax, Mr Kierath said.
At the same time, Metcash is losing market share in the eastern states, mainly to Aldi and Coles, although a recent Roy Morgan survey found IGA shoppers were the most loyal.

Morgan Stanley estimates Metcash's food and grocery sales will fall 3.8 per cent in 2016, 4.1 per cent in 2017, and 2.1 per cent in 2018 and reduce its market share from 14 per cent in 2015 to 10.3 per cent by 2020.
Last week, leading fund manager Hamish Douglass, founder of Magellan Financial Group, told a business lunch in Melbourne that Metcash was likely to disappear within a decade.
Metcash declined to respond publicly to Mr Douglass's comments.
But it is understood a Metcash director made contact with Mr Douglass last week.

IGA's market share has fallen from 18 per cent in 2010 to 14 per cent and income from Metcash's food and grocery supply business, which supplies around 1,200 IGA retailers, has dropped 43 per cent since 2012, reflecting the operational debt reduction offset by pressure on sales and margins.

The wholesaler, however, is fighting back and investing more than $150m to match Coles and Woolworths prices on hundreds of products every week and helping IGA retailers improve their stores by growing faster-growing fresh food and providing a better selection of private-label food.

Metcash's chief executive Ian Morrice says the price adjustments and shop refurbishment programs will boost Elan, and hopes the wholesaler will return to profit growth for the first time in four years in 2017.

Thanasi Kokkinakis was one of the collateral damage in the recent storm around his friend Nick Kyrgios and deserves praise rather than criticism for his own behaviour, according to Australian tennis president Steve Healy.
Kokkinakis, the younger of the talented duo regularly referred to as the "Special Ks", came to prominence following Kyrgios's infamous row with Stan Wawrinka at the Montreal Masters.

In a fiery qualifying match in Cincinnati shortly afterwards, Kokkinakis and his opponent Ryan Harrison had to be separated by the umpire twice, with Harrison shouting: "Wawrinka should have hit Kyrgios, and I should have hit the kid."
While he was last seen smashing a tennis racket after a cramp denied Richard Gasquet a potential US Open win, Kokkinakis was staunchly defended by Healy.
The teenager is currently in Glasgow, competing with Sam Groth for the second singles place behind Bernard Tomic in the Davis Cup semi-final against Britain.
"One thing that I am quite passionate about is the fact that I think Thanasi has been dragged into it a little bit,” said Healy.
He broke a racket after losing during a cramp at the US Open, but he is not the first player to break a racket in frustration, and I know Thanasi well enough to know that he is not proud of it.
But, really, he behaved extremely well in the US Open, even under the rather provocative circumstances with Harrison and so on, and I think he deserves a lot of credit.
He has a great team around him, he has a great family around him, and I think he has been treated a bit harshly.

He is a very mature 19-year-old, he works very hard, he fits into the team and so forth, he has never had a problem with other players, he is respected in the dressing room, he trains hard, he is in good shape, he is a very stable and mature young man, and I think he deserves to be judged on his own merit.

Healy also backed the decision not to include Kyrgios in the important play-off, which begins on Friday, describing the "joint decision" as the right one for all concerned, but he assured the Canberra man that he will return to the team as a long-term fixture.
"First and foremost we want the team to focus on the competition and not all the controversies around Kyrgios," Healy said.

I think Nick has risen very quickly, which people like Federer and Murray have pointed out. He's rising up in the eyes of the public, and he's made some terrible mistakes and he deserves all the criticism he gets, but we're trying to support him, we're trying to make clear the consequences of his actions. I think some time out of the limelight, just to think about things would be appropriate and it's best for the team and it's best for him.
Europe's refugee crisis: Hungary declares a state of emergency, closes the border, holds back refugees.
Hungary declared a state of emergency and sealed its southern border with Serbia on Tuesday, detaining all those who tried to enter the country illegally, in a bid to stop the influx of migrants.
Chaos ensued at the border as hundreds of migrants gathered in no-man's land and Serbian officials reacted with outrage.
The people who had fled the violence were trapped for an unknown period in a strip of land between the two countries' checkpoints and built tents and settled there.
But frustrations have risen.
As a police helicopter hovered overhead, the migrants chanted "Open the border!" and shouted insults at the Hungarian riot police.
Some protesters refused food and water in protest.
Serbia's foreign minister said it was "unacceptable" that migrants were being sent back from Hungary while more and more were arriving from Macedonia and Greece.
(Serbia) wants to be part of the solution and not a collateral damage.
Talks with Brussels and other countries must take place over the coming days," said Ivica Dacic in Prague.
The turmoil at the Hungary-Serbia border came a day after the 28-nation bloc failed to agree a common immigration policy at a contentious meeting in Brussels.

The ministers agreed to share responsibility for 40,000 people seeking refuge in overwhelmed Italy and Greece. They expressed hope that eventually - by next month or by the end of the year - an agreement would be reached for EU states to admit another 120,000 refugees, including some from Hungary.
German Chancellor Angela Merkel and Austria called for a special summit of the European Union on Tuesday to discuss the continent's immigration crisis.
Hungary, however, did not pin its hopes on quick action by Brussels or its neighbours.
The state of emergency declared in two southern regions on Tuesday gave authorities more powers to cope with the crisis, enabling them to seal off roads and speed up asylum procedures.

Meanwhile, Hungary's foreign minister Peter Szijjarto said his country is planning to erect a barbed-wire fence along its border with Romania to stop the flow of migrants through the country - after finishing a fence on its Serbian border.
CBS News correspondent Charlie D'Agata reported that even prison inmates are being used in the race to construct a barbed wire fence between Hungary and Serbia.
In recent months, Hungary has become a major bottleneck and entry point into the European Union for many war refugees from Syria and elsewhere in the Middle East.

Prime Minister Viktor Orban has insisted that most of those arriving are economic migrants looking for a better life, not war refugees who deserve protection - a view that is at odds with other EU countries, including Germany.

The new laws, which came into effect at midnight, make crossing the border or damaging the 4m (13ft) high fence which the government is building along the southern border with Serbia a crime. They also impose higher prison sentences for convicted people traffickers.
"Due to the situation caused by the mass migration, the Hungarian government has declared a state of emergency," government spokesman Zoltan Kovacs told reporters in the southern city of Szeged.
We say it very clearly: illegal border crossing is a crime.
Parliament must technically approve the military operation, expected next week, but Associated Press reporters have seen heavily armed soldiers with vehicles and dogs patrolling the border for days.
Gyorgy Bakondi, Orban's chief security advisor, said authorities caught 45 people trying to cross the border, while 15 others had penetrated deeper into the country.
They come over by damaging the fence, they are now in police custody, and they are charged with committing crimes under the new laws.
Authorities are working quickly to repair the fence.
Hungarian officials also closed two of the seven border crossings with Serbia on Tuesday morning, after a train carrying barbed wire arrived to close the borders.
Chaos engulfed the main border crossing near Roszke, Hungary, as the Hungarians opened a small office in a metal container to process people's data and a crowd pressed to get inside.
About 20 were able to get in, but thousands were left outside.
Another group of migrants blocked the main highway connecting Serbia and Hungary, saying they would refuse food and water until they are allowed to enter Hungary.
Election 2016: Hillary Clinton's lead over Bernie Sanders in national polls halved
Former US Secretary of State Hillary Clinton continues to hold a double-digit lead in the national race for the Democratic nomination, but Senator Bernie Sanders is gaining ground.
Clinton now has the support of 47 percent of Democratic voters in the primaries (58 percent previously), while Sanders is in second place with 27 percent (increased by 17 percent).
Vice President Joe Biden, who has not yet announced whether he will run for president, gets support from 15 percent of Democratic primary voters.
More than five months before the first primary votes are cast, most Democratic voters say it's too soon to say which candidate they'll support.
But Clinton's supporters are more steadfast in their preference than those of other candidates.
Since the CBS News poll, Clinton has lost ground among a number of demographic groups, while Sanders has made some gains.
Clinton holds a large lead among women and moderates, but those margins have narrowed.
His support among men has clearly waned, and Sanders is trailing by only 5 points.
Clinton's advantage among Democratic voters under age 50 has evaporated, and she and Sanders are now tied.
Clinton, however, still has a big lead among older voters.
Last month Clinton had a double-digit lead over Sanders among liberals, but Sanders now has a 5-point lead among this group.
About half of the Democratic primary voters nationwide say they would enthusiastically support Clinton if she were the party's nominee.
A quarter would support her with reservations, and another 15 percent would only support her because she is the candidate.
Six per cent would not support it.
Perhaps not surprisingly, Clinton's current supporters are overwhelmingly enthusiastic about her.
Views are more mixed among those who currently do not support Clinton - just about a quarter would enthusiastically support her.
While 48 percent of Democratic primary voters say they support Clinton enthusiastically, fewer Republican primary voters say the same about their top candidate, Donald Trump (35 percent).

When Clinton supporters are asked in an open-ended question why they want her to be the candidate, the most frequent answer is that she has the right experience (16 percent), followed by the view that it is time for a woman to be president (13 percent) and that she is the best candidate for the job (10 percent).
Among Clinton's supporters, 9 percent mention her connection to Bill Clinton.
Approval for dealing with the issues and the electability are also cited.
With the vice president weighing a potential presidential bid, 57 percent of Democratic primary voters would like to see him run — although a third thinks he should not.
When Democratic primary voters are asked who would be their second choice for the party's nomination, Biden is on top.
More than half of Clinton's supporters say Biden would be their second choice, well ahead of Sanders.
If Biden decides not to run, Clinton's lead over Sanders will increase from 20 points with Biden in the race to 30 points without him.
Fifty-five percent of Democratic voters view Clinton as the candidate with the best chance of winning the election, but that number has fallen from 78 percent last month.
Biden is a distant second on this measure, but the percentage who see him as "most electable" has risen.
Yet, when asked what is more important in a candidate, Democratic voters mention electability.
Similar to last month, not a single Democratic candidate or potential candidate for the primaries stands out as unacceptable to these voters.
Democratic candidates or potential candidates perform well on some key characteristics among voters in their party's primaries.
Majorities view Clinton, Sanders, and Biden as honest and trustworthy and possessing strong leadership qualities.
Biden scores best among the three candidates on honesty, while Clinton's strength is leadership.
Thirty percent of democratic voters don't believe Clinton is honest and trustworthy, twice as many say the same about Sanders (15 percent), but 27 percent have no opinion about him.
Democratic primary voters generally see Clinton, Sanders, and Biden as ideologically in line with their views.
In all these measurements, about a quarter of Democratic voters have no opinion of Sanders.

As questions continue to be raised about Hillary Clinton's use of a personal email address and server during her time as Secretary of State, most Democratic primary voters are satisfied with her explanation of the matter and say it has not affected their opinions overall.
But it's a different story in the American public as a whole.
Half of Americans are now unhappy with their statement, while only about one third are satisfied.
Public opinion on the issue was divided in March, soon after the problem came to light.
Most Americans said the email controversy had no effect on their overall opinion of Clinton, although 36 percent said it had made their opinion of her worse.
It is mainly Republicans, more than six in 10, who say that their views of Clinton have grown worse.

Although Clinton is seen as honest and trustworthy by Democratic voters, that remains a problem for her overall among registered voters: Just 32 percent see her as honest and trustworthy, eight points less than last month and 15 points lower than in May.
62% of eligible voters do not consider her to be an honest and trustworthy person.
At the same time, 55 percent of registered voters nationwide see Trump as not honest and trustworthy.
However, both Clinton and Trump receive good marks on leadership.
Of the six tested candidates, Biden, Carson and Bush score the highest on honesty.
A majority sees Sanders as more honest, but like Carson, many have no opinion of him.
The margin of error for the sample of 351 Democratic voters in the primary is six percentage points.
Ben Carson moves close behind Donald Trump in national poll
Ben Carson is closely behind Donald Trump in the latest CBS News/New York Times poll.
The two candidates now account for half the voters' support in the new poll, and others are losing support dramatically.

"We need energy," Trump said during a campaign appearance in Iowa on Saturday.

Five fraternity members charged with death of Baruch College freshman
Almost two years after a student died during a hazing ritual at a fraternity in Pocono Mountains, Pennsylvania, murder charges have been brought against five people.

Members of the New York City's Baruch College Pi Delta Psi fraternity brutally attacked Chun "Michael" Deng during a hazing ritual in September 2013 and delayed transporting him to the hospital, contributing to his death, police said.
Officials said he had been blindfolded and burdened with a 30-pound backpack full of sand, and repeatedly attacked as he attempted to approach a target across a frozen field.
Mr Deng eventually complained of a headache and then passed out.
Members of the Pi Delta Psi fraternity did not call 911 after Deng became unconscious and reportedly waited an hour before taking him to a hospital, police said.
But they had time to change Deng's clothes, google his symptoms and contact Andy Meng, the national president of the fraternity, for advice, police chief Chris Wagner said at a press conference.
"At that point, members began concealing items and putting the fraternity's interests over those of Michael Deng," Police Chief Wagner said.
He could not be revived and died from his injuries the following morning.
According to a post-mortem report, Deng was repeatedly subjected to blunt force trauma to the head, torso and upper legs.
"Too many families have been destroyed by hazing. At least one student dies from hazing every year since 1970," said Douglas Fierberg, a lawyer who represents Deng's family, in a statement.
Fraternities and their members must be held accountable, and this step by the authorities is very important.
A Monroe county grand jury recommended third degree murder charges for the first five members.
Thirty-two members of the brotherhood, including Mr Meng, are also charged with conducting harassment and forming a criminal organisation.

"We want to not only hold the perpetrators accountable, but if there was an organization that officially or unofficially sanctioned this, we will hold them accountable," Wagner said in a press conference on Tuesday.
Baruch College has banned the fraternity, and the national fraternity has revoked its affiliation with the local chapter.
This is what will happen when the Fed raises interest rates
A rate rise is coming, and the bull market will falter, bond yields will rise, and the economy will slide into recession.
We know that.
What we don't know is how long it will take and how long it will last.
In particular, history offers little guidance for how the economy will play out.
A recession came within 11 months of the first rate rise and lasted 86 months.
The aggressiveness of the Federal Reserve in raising interest rates is often but not always a factor in how the economy and financial markets respond.

That is why Federal Reserve officials have stressed so heavily that investors should not focus on when the central bank starts to raise interest rates, but on the length of time it will take for normalization.
In fact, several variables are at play.
In the end, market participants may find that all the excitement about a rate rise was overblown.

"The first Fed rate rise since the global financial crisis will inevitably be interpreted by some as a signal that the era of cheap money is over," Julian Jessop, chief economist at Capital Economics, said in a note to clients.
In contrast, we do not expect the gradual return of US interest rates to normal levels, but still at a low level to lead to the seismic shock that many seem to fear.
But that does not mean there will be no impact.
Here's a look at how some areas of the economy might react based on historical trends:
As the market has seen in the last month, anticipation of interest rate increases can make things volatile for a while.
Once the increase arrives, the impact is not so dramatic.

"There appears to be a tendency for asset returns to be choked off 12 to 24 months after the first hike, which may reflect the delay in monetary policy again," Deutsche Bank analysts said in a recent study of what happens to returns after Fed rate hikes.

More specifically, the market has been in an upward trend for most of the 35 years - about 14 percent - leading up to the rate hike, pretty flat in the 250 days after that (average gain of 2.6 percent), then back to normal after 500 days, with an average return in the past six cycles of 14.4 percent, according to a recent analysis published in Barron's by Bob Doll, chief investment strategist at Nuveen Asset Management.
Deutsche Bank said the effects on stocks tend to manifest later in the cycle, and that the returns start to fall.
Recessions are a fact of economic life, but interest rate increases often promote them.
In the current case, the Fed is facing some conditions that it has not had before and that could accelerate a recession.
What is noteworthy is that GDP will be near its lowest point when the Fed raises rates.
According to Deutsche Bank, only twice in the 118 rate increases since 1950 has the nominal GDP been below 4.5%.
While the second quarter of 2015 was at 3.6 percent, few expect that to continue and the Atlanta Fed is expecting only 1.5 percent for the third quarter.
Raising rates in such a fragile economic backdrop could be risky and raises the question of "whether this time is different", Deutsche Bank said.
Market participants have braced themselves for a Fed rate hike all year, and all eyes were on the Federal Open Market Committee meeting this week, which ends on Thursday.
While many strategists and economists believe the FOMC could approve an increase at this meeting, futures trading indicates only a 25 percent probability.

"Our study shows that all expansion cycles from 1950 to present have been part of a super cycle, with increasing momentum in real GDP, and have quickly surpassed pre-recession highs after the start of the recovery," the report said.
This, in contrast, is a clearly slow recovery from what was the worst recession in the observed period.
The current cycle is by far the longest the Fed has waited since the end of the last recession; the record was 35 months and this is now 74 months.
Fixed income was volatile as the market anticipates a rate hike, and the pattern is quite similar to the one in the capital market.
The main difference is that bonds react faster than stocks when they change their strategic course.
Bond yields seem to change direction once the first increase/cut in the cycle happens.
At the end of the increase cycle, bond yields will immediately fall, Deutsche Bank said.
Charles Schwab's strategists believe that the rise in interest rates will cause yields between longer and shorter bonds to converge and lead to a flattening of the curve.

High-yielding bonds usually deliver better returns in such a climate, although "we are still cautious about expecting higher yields," Kathy Jones, a fixed-income analyst at Schwab, wrote in an analysis.
It's interesting, Jones says, that markets have already adjusted to Fed strategy expectations.
"Along with the dollar's strength and the decline in inflation expectations, there are some signs that the market has adjusted to the prospect of tighter monetary policy," she wrote.
Short-term rates have risen, the yield curve has flattened, credit spreads have widened and volatility has increased - all hallmarks of a market when the Fed is tightening its strategy.
Overall, companies that do most of their business in the US will benefit if interest rates rise and local products become more attractive.
Multinationals with high debts will be worse off as a rising dollar makes their products more expensive on global markets and also increases the cost of financing their debts.
"History shows that Quality stocks tend to react very positively three months after an initial rate hike," Goldman Sachs analysts said in a note to clients.
Firms with strong balance sheets have outperformed those with weak balance sheets by an average of 5 percentage points after each rate increase in 1994, 1999 and 2004.
Firms with high capital returns and low stock market volatility outperformed their low-quality counterparts by an average of 4 and 3 percentage points respectively.
Debt is going to be a big problem.
Companies with a high proportion of floating-rate debt will suffer the most, Goldman said.
Outside of pure stock plays, consumers will also benefit from the rising dollar.
Savers may see gains through higher returns, although experts are divided on how quickly this will happen.

The BBC Music Awards, which started last year, seem to be The Brits under a different name.

What I learn about classical music from Radio 3, I will not learn anywhere else.
