Internet sales grew at their slowest pace in August, and Black Friday may be to blame.
In the first three months of 2015, there was a seven percent increase in online sales.
Last month the figure was the lowest since records began in 2000.
Online sales were boosted three years ago by the use of mobile phones for shopping.
Experts believe that Black Friday in November slowed spending.
For over a decade, online shopping has boomed, and many of Britain's high streets have turned into ghost towns.
But experts say there are now signs that online sales are stagnating, after new figures showed only seven per cent growth in the first three months of 2015.
Total spending for August showed the lowest growth since records began in 2000 with just a 5% rise on the previous year.
Experts say there are signs that online sales are stalling after new figures showed growth of just seven percent in the first three months of 2015.
"If you look at the growth rates for previous years and go back to 2000, it has grown over time," Andy Mulcahy, the editor of the IMRG sales index, told the Guardian.
He said that online sales had increased three years ago as buyers started making purchases with their phones.
It meant more people could shop online and that people could do it in different environments, for example on the sofa at home.
But now it is settling down, and we may see growth slow down.
The Black Friday phenomenon, imported from America, is cited as one of the reasons for the falling sales.
Experts believe shoppers hold back their purchases ahead of the event, which takes place on the last Friday in November.
Last year, five times the average number of shoppers flocked to their computers to make their bargains, and some retailer websites crashed.
Experts believe that Black Friday, when shoppers fought over bargains, could deter shoppers from making purchases.
A study by the British Retail Consortium found that out of £5 spent, more than £1 was spent online.
For some products, such as TVs and washing machines, more than a third of purchases are now made online.
At the same time, more than a quarter of people buy clothes and shoes online, rather than in high street shops.
Muslims bury those killed in Mecca crane crash - Bin Laden family is sanctioned
The bodies of 29 dead are carried through the streets of Mecca by Muslims for the first burials
Saudi Arabia blames part of the collapse on the huge Saudi Bin Laden Group.
The health ministry said a total of 394 people were injured after the crane collapsed
Hundreds of Muslims gathered as 29 victims were carried through the streets to be buried, killed when a crane collapsed at Mecca's Grand Mosque.
Mourners, dressed largely in white, filled the route to pay their respects as the first of the dead began their final journey to the Al-Moaissem cemetery.
The funeral procession passed the holy site where, just days earlier, a construction crane crashed through the roof of the mosque and onto worshippers below.
The bodies were released for burial after Saudi King Abdullah imposed a sanction against the Bin Laden family construction company over the disaster, which also left 394 people injured.
The bodies of the 29 worshippers killed when a crane crashed through the Grand Mosque in Mecca were carried through the streets.
Among the dead was Qasim Akram from Bolton, Greater Manchester, a father of four, who was on his first pilgrimage when the crane collapsed.
Mr Akram was with his parents inside the Grand Mosque before the start of the annual Hajj pilgrimage.
Saudi officials have already promised that the Hajj pilgrimage to Mecca will go on with thousands more still coming to the city.
Today, King Salman said that the bin laden group should not have left the crane arm standing when it was not in use.
An Arabic version of the decree published by the state-run Saudi Press Agency said the Bin Laden Group was partly to blame for the collapse.
The English-language service of the news agency did not report this detail, but said that the company's management was banned from travelling abroad.

Earlier this week, Salman promised to reveal what caused the crane to fall into the courtyard of the Grand Mosque, where hundreds of thousands of Muslims were gathered ahead of the Hajj pilgrimage, which takes place later this month.
The Bin Laden Group has made no statement about the crane collapse, and its representatives were not available for comment.
The royal decree also criticised the group for not having up-to-date security measures and for not cooperating with meteorologists.
Dozens of cranes surround Mecca's Grand Mosque as part of a massive construction project overseen by the Bin Laden Group.
The Bin Laden family has been linked to the Saudi royal family for decades and undertakes major building projects.
The late al-Qaeda leader Osama bin Laden was a disinherited son who was cut off from his family in the 1990s.

The crane crash came amid strong winds and rain, just days before the arrival of millions in the kingdom for the pilgrimage, which is required of all able-bodied Muslims at least once in their lifetime.
Officials said 158 people remained in hospital.
Government representatives ordered that 1 million rials (£174,000) be paid to the families of people killed and the same amount to those permanently injured.
Other injured persons will receive half of that amount.
B&Q boss says the era of cheap eastern European tradesmen is over

At the moment, the employees are predominantly male.

Mrs Laury said: "There's still a majority of men working in our branches.

Women play a big role in the decision-making process.

Kingfisher is one of the few companies to have exactly 50 per cent of its workforce as women, including its top management and CFO.
Mrs Laury said: "This was a conscious decision - diversity is an important issue here.
It was not difficult to find good women for our supervisory board.
Kingfisher reported a fall in half-year profits and sales after shouldering the costs of closing stores.
Because of the trend, Kingfisher, which owns Screwfix and B&Q, will open 200 new stores.
Officials from Aich/Dob facing trial for fraud
Two executives of Austrian volleyball club Aich/Dob faced charges of embezzlement and tax evasion at a regional court in Klagenfurt on Wednesday.
The defendants pleaded not guilty.
One of them had also faced charges of abuse of power.
He was acquitted of this charge in May.
The current process has been postponed.

According to the prosecutor, Robert Riffel, in the preliminary investigation it appeared that the defendants had used funds from the club's accounts, which they were entitled to dispose of in their functions, for private purposes between 2006 and 2011.
He estimates the damage at about 400,000 euros.
The sports officials are also charged with financial wrongdoing.
This fact excluded the presiding judge of the jury, Michaela Sanin, from the proceedings.
This is expected to be negotiated at a later date.
The defense alleged that the club had suffered no financial loss at any time.

The sports officials had only charged expenses and pulled the sports club, for which they were active from 1982 to 2011 and in which they had invested much time and money, out of the debt - the liabilities were about 600,000 schillings (about 44,000 euros) in 2001 .
"We had to decide whether to continue the club or to shut it down," one of the defendants, who was a tax inspector by profession, told the court.
Together with his colleague and co-accused, he then decided to take on the task.
At all risks.
“We had borrowed money, we had put our life insurance policies as collateral with the bank,” he said at the hearing.
The agreement with the club was that they could manage the money freely, but no debts were allowed.
Moreover, it was decided that if the financial situation was successful, the payment of the expense allowances would be paid retroactively to 1991.
Therefore, they had paid out a part of the expenses only years later, namely from the year 2003, when there had been a profit on the account.
Therefore, lump-sum and not detailed payments appeared, the former chairman explained the proceedings.
The accounts and savings books were managed jointly by the two defendants, the second defendant said.
Why the payments to the club were not disclosed in detail, the judge asked.
The association was not interested in the details of the financial situation and the only important thing was that the club was debt free, came the answer.
When an official was investigated for corruption in 2011, 120,000 euros were transferred to the club's account.
These were reserves, the defendants explained.
This securities account was in the name of the second defendant and, according to his statement, was not known to the association.

Surely David Cameron knows The Lorax better?
It is something that all parents learn soon enough: if your child loves a book, it won’t be long before you know it almost by heart.
Unless you're David Cameron perhaps.
When asked by a provider of childcare systems to name his favourite children’s book, the Prime Minister opted for The Lorax, the 1971 environmental fable by Dr Seuss.

It was a difficult choice, Cameron writes in a message on the SuperCamps website, adding: "funny, moving, creative and with a powerful message, it's a book I love reading to my kids, as there always seems to be a picture or message we've missed."

All well and good, except that the following paragraph in which Cameron supposedly describes the book's plot is instead a synopsis of the 2012 film version, which added new characters and details to expand the fairly brief original text.

"In the midst of the walled city of Thneed-Ville, where all nature has gone and even the air is a commodity, a boy named Ted hopes to win the heart of Audrey, the girl of his dreams, by fulfilling her wish to see a real tree," reads the description. A love interest was Dr. Seuss, whose real name was Theodor Seuss Geisel, and who died in 1991, but completely unknown.

As if that weren't suspicious enough, Cameron's text reads in part like a summary of the Lorax movie presented on the Internet Movie Database's website, which begins, "In the walled city of Thneed-Ville, where everything is artificial and even the air is a commodity, a boy named Ted hopes to win the heart of Audrey, the girl of his dreams."

Though he admits to being a pragmatic father, it seems unlikely that Cameron is so unfamiliar with the story. In it, an unnamed boy hears how the local environment is being ruined by the money-grabbing, tree-chopping, Thneed-knitting Once-ler, despite the protests of the Lorax, a squat, mustachioed creature "who speaks for the trees".
Most likely such a relatively low PR task was delegated to an aide who has not read The Lorax 20 times in a row to a child.
A Downing Street spokeswoman said the text was likely to have come from Cameron's constituency office.
SuperCamps confirmed that the text was supplied by Cameron's staff but gave no further immediate comment.

The Brexit camp could gain momentum if the economy runs into a slump by 2017.

David Cameron's unformed renegotiation strategy for keeping Britain in the EU gets deeper into trouble every day, even before the election of the brilliant Jeremy "Is it Yes or No?" Corbyn as Labour leader or the TUC's fierce split over Europe on Tuesday.
Foreigners also have their Corbyns and Nigel Farages.

A European diplomatic friend said recently that some member states, so deeply entangled in various crises as the EU is now and not always of its own making, are fed up with the UK's own agenda of divided concessions and disruptive treaty changes that they mostly do not want.
At the TUC's annual conference in Brighton, the union decided that it did not like that either if it jeopardised social protection.
We could call it Dave and George's selfie agenda.

Prime ministers and finance ministers climb up summit meetings or bilateral meetings in foreign capitals, take a photo of themselves in front of a famous local monument, with or without local dignitaries, then come home and say they have acquired allies for reforms.
It's always about me.

My European friend, who wants an outward looking Britain inside the EU tent - "Don't leave us alone with France" says Berlin - and lets it be known that more and more short-sighted ministers and officials in some capitals have come to the point where they don't care whether we stay or go.

Germany's cautious and composed Chancellor Angela Merkel is an ally, but she has been in power for 10 years and wants to leave office before it looks bad for her, as has happened with those who have stayed too long like Thatcher (11 years), Mitterrand (14) and Kohl (16).
France's François Hollande is looking ahead to either his re-election or his replacement in 2017.
He is also a fading force.
Poland may soon have a nationalist right-wing government and Spain a left-wing one.

It's hard to imagine that they will go out of their way to help the selfie Brits, whose energy would better be spent in keeping Scotland from leaving the UK - something they don't want either, since most of them have similar separatist tendencies.
So some such ministers may even be planning deliberately unhelpful comments, in SNP style, during Britain's referendum campaign in 2017, to speed up the Brexit process, my friend speculates.
"The renegotiation has been a failure" and "Britain has won nothing of value from the renegotiation."

The Europeans know how rapacious Fleet Street can be at their expense and how EU-sceptic the oligarchy of press barons is, as they were not during the Tony Benn-inspired referendum of 1975, which endorsed our entry in 1973 by a margin of two to one.
You may dimly recall Boris Johnson, the arch-euro opportunist, who made his name as a "straight bananas" Brussels correspondent in the early 1990s.
For all his craziness, Ed Miliband knew who his enemies were.
This included a medley of tax-fearing villains, phone-hacking foreigners and pseudo non-doms who own most of our great newspapers.
Tony Blair had a similar view, but realised that when you are in a hot cage with a gorilla, it is better to hand out bananas to distract him rather than to become his lunch and dinner.

Indeed, Miliband was more Blairite than Blair himself when he resisted Cameron's referendum frenzy, since Blair had put principle before the unratified EU constitution, which was then rejected by French and Dutch voters in 2005, giving him a back door.
The press never fully forgave him for this.

But the nice Mr Corbyn, who gave me a friendly slap on the back in Westminster on Monday - I told him he didn't need to waste time on me any more - seems to be in danger of repeating Neil Kinnock's 80s boycott Murdoch strategy, a mistake then and now.
It may take time, but he must develop a coherent strategy to win over the media, not just with me, but certainly with Andrew Marr, whose BBC sofa he left on Sunday.
Corbyn's official position on Europe is, to put it politely, in development.
He says we should stay in a reformed EU.
Well, most people outside Ukip's traditional blue rinse tendency and the wilder shores of Tory little Englandism could probably agree with that.

It's what Hilary "one Benn but not a Bennite" Benn said on radio and TV this week as the boy scout in him struggled not to admit that Corbyn's appointment of the provocative John McDonnell as shadow chancellor was a bad idea.
It reminded me of the 1970s when his old dad was on tv trying to be disloyal to his Labour cabinet colleagues without going too far and losing his cabinet job.
Hillary's fight was even more attractive.
But to "fight on under all circumstances" - Benn's phrase - was not what McDonnell said, nor what JC reportedly told his comrades and MPs at their away day on Monday night.

Whatever the rousing, bottom-up image that Corbyn wants to project - and remember he has even moved me - news discipline is important in the age of 24-hour TV and above all in the whirl of social media, a breeding ground for paranoia and betrayal.
It is right that Cameron should not be given a free pass to Europe, which allows him to take Labour’s backing in the referendum campaign for granted, as McDonnell said.
Simon Jenkins probably thinks so.

But McDonnell and Corbyn's fundamental ambiguities over EU membership - in keeping with their Bennite siege economy, their anti-capitalist pasts - is no longer just a matter of esoteric discussion among left-wing dissidents for whom the narcissism of small differences is a central principle of dogmatic disputes.
As with his ambiguities over Nato - Tom Watson is adamant that JC won't launch an exit campaign - foreign diplomats will be obliged to try to make sense of it all for their superiors back home.
Why should Paris or Berlin waste political capital - they have sceptical voters too - making concessions to the British if it might all be for nothing?

Experts criticize Public Health England report on e-cigarettes

Claims made by a government-funded agency that electronic cigarettes are less harmful than smoking resulted from a meeting of 12 people, some with links to the tobacco industry, researchers have said.
Experts writing in the British Medical Journal (BMJ) joined The Lancet in criticising the evidence used by Public Health England (PHE) in its report on e-cigarettes.
PHE published the "principle report" last month, describing it as a "comprehensive review of the evidence".
But some researchers have questioned the data's reliability and pointed to links between some of the experts and the tobacco industry.
An editorial in the medical journal The Lancet last month attacked the "remarkably flimsy basis" on which PHE had based its key conclusion.
Two other researchers writing in BMJ have asked whether the claims are built on rock or sand.

Martin McKee, professor of European public health at the London School of Hygiene and Tropical Medicine and Simon Capewell, professor of clinical epidemiology at the University of Liverpool, said: "One fundamental principle of public health is that strategies should be based on evidence of effectiveness."

They said that the public expects PHE's claim that "the current best estimate is that e-cigarettes are around 95% less harmful than smoking" to be based on a detailed review of the evidence and modelling.

In fact, this statement comes from a single meeting of 12 people convened to develop a model for a multi-criteria decision analysis (MCDA) to synthesise their opinions on the harms of various nicotine-containing products; the results of the meeting were summarised in a research report.

McKee and Capewell said that a sponsor of the meeting was a company called EuroSwiss Health, whose directors had allegedly previously received funds from British American Tobacco (BAT) for an independent study.
He also signed off on BAT's public health references in a sustainability report, they said.

One of the 12 participants in the meeting said that they received funding from an e-cigarette maker, but not the funding they had reportedly previously received from tobacco company Philip Morris International, they added.
The reasons for selecting the panel members are not provided, but they include several well-known e-cigarette champions, some of whom also disclose industry funding in the paper.
Some of the other participants in this meeting are not known for their expertise in tobacco control.
PHE tobacco control leads also attended the meeting.
The group's research "admits that there is a lack of 'hard evidence' of harm from most products for most criteria", wrote McKee and Capewell.
However, none of these connections or restrictions are discussed in the PHE report.
McKee and Capewell said PHE's claim that "there is currently no evidence that e-cigarettes are acting as a route into smoking for children or non-smokers" was premature.
Prof Kevin Fenton, director of health and wellbeing at PHE, said that BMJ's claims had already been responded to.
He said: "E-cigarettes are considerably less harmful than smoking."
Half of all lifetime smokers die as a result of their addiction.
All the evidence suggests that the health risks of e-cigarettes are much lower than ordinary cigarettes, but that we still need to study the long-term effects.
PHE has a clear duty to inform the public about what the evidence shows and what it does not, especially when there is so much public confusion about the relative risks compared to smoking.
Almost 80,000 people die each year from smoking-related diseases, and smoking costs the NHS £2bn a year.
By clearly setting out the current evidence that e-cigarettes are not risk-free but are far less harmful than smoking, we are fulfilling our national responsibility.

Former Channel 4 chairman Luke Johnson has said the BBC should stop broadcasting shows like EastEnders and The Voice. He said commercial rivals would "give their right arm" for hit shows like the Albert Square soap.

After BBC director general, Tony Hall, said the corporation wanted to do more in partnership with other organisations, Johnson said he had tried, unsuccessfully, to get in touch with the BBC during his six years at channel 4.

"I have a problem with the idea that the BBC would commission or put out programmes which would also be clearly shown by non-subsidised competitors," Mr Johnson told the House of Lords Communications Committee as part of its inquiry into the future of the BBC.
If you want to keep the broadcasting fee, which I do not think is a good idea in the medium to long term, one should at least focus its production on programmes that others do not make or commission.
They are broadcasting The Voice in a prime-time slot because they want to garner as much support as possible for the show's future.
The idea that nobody else would show this is a joke, it is ridiculous, it is obviously nonsense.
Johnson said: "I don't see why a regressive tax should fund programmes that could be funded without subsidy."
The Voice is one such programme, Eastenders is another, albeit both self produced.
To be honest, other channels would give their right arm for this.
I'm trying to see how this is supposed to be public broadcasting.
I don't think this would reduce the BBC at all.

Johnson, a series entrepreneur who ran Channel 4 from 2004 to 2010, said the BBC was to blame for chasing ratings "because of the ambitions of the people who work there and because they believe it's the best way to secure long-term support."

Johnson said that the more publicly funded niche programmes should ‘go to BBC4, where you can’t really measure the audience but they fulfil their remit, and they can argue when they go on their sort of hypocritical missions to justify £4bn of broadcasting licence fee, “Well, of course we have created all these obscure programmes that nobody has seen.”
They put them in a time window in which no one ever wanted to see them.
Johnson told the committee on the licence fee: "I challenge you to find a more regressive system in terms of who gets the best value out of it.

Of course you all think, we all think, that you get very good value here for £150 a year, but for people for whom £150 is a lot of money, I wonder whether that's true, because they don't consume much of the BBC.
Former Sky and Channel 5 boss David Elstein, who also gave evidence to the committee on Tuesday, called for the BBC to review its Reithian mission to "inform, educate and entertain".

He said that only a small percentage of the BBC's output would now officially be classified as education - he said it was 1% of its TV output and 0.1% on radio - and it should follow the example of publicly funded TV broadcasters in Australia and Canada in changing this to "inform, educate and entertain".

On the subject of partnerships, Elstein said the BBC should do more in areas such as the Proms, of which he said only a handful are shown on TV, and form alliances with commercial broadcasters to make everything available online.

The impulses are generated by activating motor neuron cells that have been genetically engineered to carry membrane channels that respond to ultrasound waves.

The researchers said the worms showed the power of a new technique called sonogenetics that can use ultrasound to activate a range of brain, heart and muscle cells outside the body.

Sreekanth Chalasani, a researcher at the Salk Institute in La Jolla, California, told the Guardian that the procedure could one day replace deep brain stimulation, an invasive procedure that delivers electrical impulses into the brain of humans to treat symptoms of Parkinson’s disease.
Worms generally do not respond to ultrasound, but Chalasani found they did when they were surrounded by a liquid containing microscopic air bubbles.
The bubbles, he discovered, amplify the ultrasound waves, which then penetrate into the worms.
The enhanced ultrasound waves act on structures called TRP-4 ion channels, which are found in the membranes of some of the worm cells.
The sound waves cause the ion channels to open, activating the cells to which they are attached, according to a report in Nature Communications.
To create the ultrasound-controlled nematodes, Chalasani genetically engineered the worms so that some of their motor neurons carry TRP-4 ion channels.
When he applies ultrasound to the modified creatures, the sound waves are amplified by the microbubbles and transmitted into the worms, where they activate the modified motor neurons.
The process has some similarities with optogenetics, a groundbreaking tool that allows scientists to switch neurons on and off with pulses of light.
But Chalasani said that sonogenetics could have some advantages over this technique.

Unlike light, which must be sent down an optical fibre to the desired location in the brain, low-frequency ultrasound waves can pass through tissue unimpeded, and so can be sent into the brain from above the skull.

"We believe that with gene therapy and a therapeutic virus, it is possible to make targeted human neurons temporarily susceptible to the ultrasound signal in a clinical setting for certain neurological treatments," Chalasani said.
Other applications might focus on muscle cells and insulin-producing cells, he added.

Eight golden rules for life in student dormitories

Eleven years ago, I moved into student halls as a self-absorbed 19-year-old, still believing in berets and moral relativism, but it is only now that I remember the strained smiles of those I annoyed - and the numerous, lengthy complaints about others.
Most of what I have learned can be distilled into eight simple rules.
Moving into student accommodation can range from mildly nerve-wracking to absolutely terrifying.

It's tempting to gossip: people tell you where you're from, whether and where you've taken a gap year, where you stand on Corbyn, and why you "honestly don't love or hate marmite because like guys, it's literally just yeast extract HAHAHA, I'm in my room."
Breathe in.
And help others to do the same - ask questions and show an interest.
It directs the conversation and helps you find out who you like in contrast to who you wouldn't speak to even if your eyelashes went on fire and these were fire extinguishers.
Let people.
People's rooms often turn into drink receptions, film night venues, and communal meeting places, but they are also the places where people get dressed and adjust their underwear.
In that sense, don't think about starting a relationship at the university.
Introverts get a rough deal at university.
Your room should be a refuge, but many student halls foster a corridor culture that is sociable and friendly and can lead to lifelong friendships.
It can be hell for somebody trying to recover.
Nothing in the culture allows you to say: "I like you, and I want our friendship to continue, but you must go away so that I can regain the energy I spent on interacting with you."
Try to sense when a classmate is exhausted from sociability - and send him a text message instead of knocking.
Speaking of knocking: Do it.
A guy in my dorm had the idea that an unlocked door was an invitation.
He saw some things.
Make friends through baking.

As you start university at the peak of the bake-off mania, the knocking on doors from people bearing plates of brownies seems less strange than 1950s-style greetings of "Welcome to the neighbourhood, I've baked you something. So, and now please smile while I ask you a few personal questions."
Offering home made delicacies is a good way to make friends.
Your roommates will feel obligated to chat and might associate your face with a delicious treat by the end.
Of course, this depends on whether you are a decent baker.
Badly mixed lumps of flour, sugar and fat cause people to pretend to be asleep when you knock.
Stealing food is a common crime in student dormitories.
Of course, stealing a chicken is theft, but is taking a drop of milk for your tea?
Check with the milk owner.
There is a good chance that they will serve themselves even if they cook inside.
If someone steals your stuff, it's annoying, and you have my sympathy - but try to deal with it more fairly than my housemate, who added soap to her milk to punish thieves.
She is now in prison.
You should not make noise that prevents people from sleeping or working.
It's not just about being a nice person, but you are, in the truest sense of the word, one of the people who sit in the glass house.
A girl on my corridor asked her neighbours if they could turn down the drum & bass because it was three in the morning and she had an exam in the morning.

When they finally stopped at 5am, she let her neighbours sleep for another two hours before blaring her own music, locking her door and heading off to her three-hour exam.
Wouldn't it be romantic if your future spouse would move into the same student dormitory by chance?

Would it not be downright embarrassing if you were to mistake your future spouse for a flatmate, hit on her, then break up and have to see her every day and maybe watch as she draws all your common friends to her side?
Of course, the heart has its own reasons - but if your hot roommate is definitely not your future spouse, try to talk some sense into your lower body.
In the exciting moment when you notice that someone has left his keys in his unlocked room, the line between a prank and bullying is finer than it seems.
A good joke is funny, but it only takes a moment before it turns into a boomerang.
Teach a valuable and amusing lesson about security by hiding - but never ruin someone's room with toothpaste and shampoo.
Lock your door and put your keys in a glass of water and put it in the freezer - but don't nail your possessions to the ceiling more than twice.

On their most anticipated meeting of the year, Federal Reserve policymakers will spend two days this week sitting around a 27-foot Honduran mahogany table, deciding whether it is time to raise interest rates for the first time in nearly a decade.
Looming over them at one end of the ornate, two-storey meeting room is a mural of the United States.
The chart is a reminder that Fed chairwoman Janet L. Yellen and her colleagues should put the nation's economic interests first.
The Federal Reserve has a dual mandate from Congress: to maximize US employment and to keep prices stable here.
But since the Great Recession, Fed leaders have acknowledged there is an unwritten third mandate: financial stability.

And that third mandate could be the X factor in a decision that's too close to call. It will be announced on Thursday whether the US economy is ready to be weaned off the unprecedented stimulus of near zero short-term interest rates since the end of 2008.

While most data shows the economy is growing solidly, the recent turbulence in global financial markets could cause the already cautious Fed officials to worry about exacerbating that volatility by raising the federal funds rate - even if only by a quarter point.
"Clearly, the labor market and inflation are going to be the primary things they're going to be focused on," said Lindsey M. Piegza, chief economist at brokerage firm Stifel Nicolaus & Co.
"But I think if they were looking for an excuse not to raise rates, the heightened uncertainty around the global market is enough justification to continue to wait," she said.
There is no consensus on what the Fed will do, which in itself unsettles the financial markets.
About half of the economists surveyed recently by Bloomberg predicted a rate rise this week.
But financial markets are expecting the Fed to hold off, with one key indicator showing only a 30% chance of a rise.
This suggests that the stock market could fall if the Fed raises rates, unless strategists cushion the blow by promising that any further rise is a long way off.
On Tuesday the Dow Jones Industrial Average jumped 228.89 points, or 1.4%, to 16,599.85.
The move was prompted by expectations that the Fed will maintain its stance this week, said John Lonski, chief economist at Moody's Capital Markets Research Group.
It would be a surprise if the Fed raised rates at this point, he said.
If it does, "it would have to go very far in its statement to calm financial markets so they don't panic."
Other experts argued that a rate increase would calm financial markets because it would remove uncertainty about when the Fed will act.

Just last month, the Fed seemed on course to raise rates by 0.25 percentage points this month, the first small step in a gradual tightening of monetary conditions that would test the strength of the US recovery.
Yellen had said in the spring and summer that she expected to raise the rate this year despite complaints from liberals that more economic progress was needed.
Although job creation slowed in August, improvement in the labor market this year has been solid.
The unemployment rate fell to 5.1% last month, the lowest in more than seven years and near the level the Fed regards as full employment.
Wage increases have shown signs of recovery.
And although inflation has consistently run below the central bank's 2% annual target, Fed representatives said the main reason was the temporary effect of significantly lower oil prices.
"The economy can handle higher rates and needs them because of the strain on the labor market," said Ian Shepherdson, chief economist at Pantheon Macroeconomics.
But financial markets around the world jolted last month when China devalued its currency.
The Dow Jones Industrial Average fell more than 16% below its May peak as investors feared that a slowdown in the Chinese economy would throttle global growth.
The market has recovered somewhat this month, with the Dow now down almost 10% from its May peak.
For Fed representatives, the market turbulence affects the complex calculation of when to raise interest rates.

"If the events in the financial markets and the news about the weakness in the Chinese economy had not occurred in the past few weeks, they would be tightening in this meeting," said Stephen D. Oliner, senior research fellow at the UCLA Ziman Center for Real Estate and a former Fed staff member.
Now he predicts that she will wait at least another month to better gauge the effects.
"There is a lot of uncertainty about what the impact will be on the US economy and there are almost no reliable data describing developments in China," said Oliner.
The health of the global economy is not one of the Fed's core concerns, so it should not technically be factored into its decision-making.
But in the end, the Fed has become the world's currency regulator.
The central bank's influence has been enormous in recent years.
Mere mention by then-chairman Ben S. Bernanke in 2013 that the Fed might "taper" its monetary expansion triggered confusion around the globe.

In a world in which markets and economies are increasingly intertwined, it is expected that Fed representatives will not only monitor developments elsewhere, but also consult with other central banks and experts to gain a better understanding of the global economy.
Their decision-making is "more art than science," said Zachary Karabell, head of global strategy at wealth management firm Envestnet Inc.

Jeffrey Lacker, president of the Federal Reserve Bank of Richmond, Va., noted this month that "the Fed has a history of overreacting to financial market movements that are not apparently connected to economic fundamentals."
Lacker, a voting member of the Federal Open Market Committee, who favours a rate rise, cited decisions in 1998/1999 as an example.
A financial crisis in Asia prompted the Fed to lower its benchmark rate by three-quarters of a percentage point in three meetings "despite limited apparent effects on US growth", Lacker said.
A year later, Fed representatives reversed these cuts.

The Fed should only put financial stability at the top of its agenda during a severe crisis like the market collapse of 2008, said Adam S. Posen, a former member of the Bank of England's rate-setting committee.
The recent turbulence is not anywhere close to that level, he said.
"She does not want to get into a situation where she is afraid of raising rates because the markets are going crazy," said Posen, president of the Peterson Institute for International Economics.
The Federal Reserve Act still contains the dual mandate and does not mention financial stability, and until that is changed, I do not think it should go ahead.

For overweight diabetics, weight-loss surgery can be helpful.
The benefits of weight loss surgery for mildly obese people with type 2 diabetes may last at least five years, according to a new study.
It's too early to say whether overweight people with diabetes live longer after weight loss surgery than those who receive non-surgical treatment.
"Mortality data takes a long time to show something," said Dr. Robin Blackstone, an expert in weight-loss surgery who wrote an editorial accompanying the new study in JAMA Surgery.
Weight loss surgery, or bariatric surgery, uses different methods to reduce the size of the stomach.
They reduce appetite and limit the body's ability to absorb food.
Over the years, bariatric surgery has proved effective in treating type 2 diabetes, but most studies have been done in people who are morbidly obese with a body mass index (BMI) of 35 or higher.
BMI, a certain measure of weight in relation to height, is considered normal between 18.5 and 24.9.
A BMI of 25 or more indicates that someone is overweight, and people with a BMI of over 30 are considered to be obese.
You can calculate your BMI here: 1.usa.gov/1D0ZqDv.

For the new study, researchers from Taiwan's Min-Sheng General Hospital used data they had collected since 2007 in a study that compared two types of obesity surgery - gastric bypass and gastric banding - to medical treatments for type 2 diabetes in people who were mildly obese.
The average BMI among those who underwent this operation fell from 31 to 24.5 by the end of the fifth year of this study.
Meanwhile, BMI remained about the same at 29 for those receiving non-surgical diabetes treatments.
Of those who underwent the surgery, 36% of the cases of diabetes went into remission, and in 28% of the cases there was a significant improvement.
In the medically treated group, by comparison, the diabetes resolved completely in only one percent and partially in only about two percent.
In addition, the results for blood pressure, triglycerides and "bad" LDL cholesterol were "generally better in the surgical group", the authors found.
The researchers also monitored patients' blood levels of hemoglobin A1c, which reflects blood sugar levels over time.
HbA1c should be kept below 7 percent, the researchers write.
After the surgery, the average HbA1c level dropped from about 9% to about 6%.
In the medical therapy group it remained stable at about 8 percent.
But this better "glycemic control" — as reflected in the improved hemoglobin A1c levels — did not reduce mortality in five years, lead researcher Dr. Chih-Cheng Hsu and colleagues reported.
The research team also compared average outcomes for the two types of surgery.

At 5 years, the bypass group had lost more weight compared with the gastrectomy group (18.7 vs 14.2 kg), achieved greater decreases in BMI (7.4 vs 5.1), and HbA1c (3.1% vs 2.1%) and had more complete diabetes resolution (46.9% vs 16.7%).

While the new study showed no survival advantage to surgery after five years, there are hints from a study of heavier people in Sweden that surgery leads to a longer life, says Blackstone of the University of Arizona College of Medicine Phoenix.
In the Swedish study, obese people who had weight-loss surgery were about 29% less likely to die over 15 years compared to a group that tried more conventional methods.
Although the new study did not show a survival advantage for surgery patients, Blackstone said it was reassuring for people with a BMI below 35 who are interested in the procedure.
'That's the critical point of this study, because it says that that operation in this lower BMI group is lower without an increased risk of death or kidney disease,' she said.
Blackstone added that people and their doctors should start to take weight seriously as soon as a patient has a BMI of between 27 and 30.
"I think we wait too long to get people to take this seriously," she said.
I think that once they have accumulated these genetic changes that have tied their bodies to obesity and diabetes, reversal is really hard."

Four-fold increase in child hand sanitizer use in last 4 years
Poison control centers in the US are reporting a nearly 400% increase in the number of children under 12 who have swallowed highly alcoholic hand sanitizers, according to the Georgia Poison Center.

According to Dr. Gaylord Lopez, director of the Georgia Poison Center, cases of ingestion of hand sanitizers among children under 12 reported to poison control centers rose from 3,266 in 2010 to 16,117 in 2014.
"Kids are coming across these products more and more often, and unfortunately a percentage of them are ending up in emergency rooms," Lopez told CNN.
He said some children deliberately drink disinfectants, while others do it to impress their friends or as a dare on social media.
Videos on YouTube show teenagers drinking disinfectant for a cheap thrill.
Allegedly, teenagers have mixed disinfectant with alcoholic mouthwash to get a stronger drink.
Younger children can be attracted to the attractive smells of disinfectants.
"A child doesn't think this is bad for them," Lopez said.
Many of the more attractive hand sanitizing products are those that are perfumed.
There are disinfectants with strawberry, grape and orange scents that are very attractive to children.
Hand sanitizers contain somewhere between 45% and 95% alcohol.
Even just a few drops can lead to alcohol poisoning, particularly in young children.
"It is highly concentrated alcohol," Dr Stephen Thornton, medical director of the Poison Control Center at the University of Kansas Hospital, told Fox 4 in Kansas City.
So you would not leave a shot of whisky lying around, but people leave these hand sanitizers within reach of children, and if children get hold of it, it is a quick way to consume a lot of alcohol.
Nhaijah Russell, a six year old girl who recently ingested four squirts of strawberry-scented hand sanitizer at school, was taken to an emergency room for treatment.
Her blood alcohol level was 179, twice the legal threshold for intoxication for an adult, said Dr. Chris Ritchey, an emergency room doctor who treated her at Gwinnett Medical Center outside Atlanta.
Nhaijah slurred her words and was unable to walk when she arrived at the emergency room.
Doctors monitored her overnight in a separate children's hospital for signs of brain trauma because the girl had fallen while intoxicated and hit her head, Ritchey said.
"It was very scary," Ortoria Scott, Nhaijah's mother, told CNN.
It could have been fatal to my child.
Lopez recommended that parents and teachers use alcohol-free products or wipes and store hand sanitizer out of children's reach.
In addition to alcohol poisoning, some disinfectants have been linked to deaths.
In 2013, two women in Ontario died after swallowing hand sanitizer that contained a toxic, undeclared ingredient.
Health officials suspect the product contained methanol, a toxic solution, instead of ethyl alcohol, which was listed as the active ingredient.

Unemployment in Scotland remains unchanged, while it rises overall in the United Kingdom.
Scotland's unemployment rate was unchanged at 164,000 between May and July, while the number of people out of work in the UK as a whole rose by 10,000 over the same period to 1.82 million.
Scotland's unemployment rate of 5.9% was higher than the UK's 5.5%, according to figures from the Office for National Statistics (ONS).

Why I will be a witness to an execution in Oklahoma
Later today, barring a late legal intervention, I will watch a man be put to death.
If it happens, and I hope it doesn't, I'll be sitting in a witness gallery in the death chamber at Oklahoma State Penitentiary when Richard Glossip is executed by lethal injection.
He asked me to be one of the four official witnesses to his death.
The invitation was first made in January via his best friend, and whilst I was shocked, I agreed.
As the day drew nearer, I began to fear.
So why should I do it?
I agreed because I thought it would be a good opportunity to tell the whole story about the death penalty.
It would offer a unique perspective.
It is true that journalists are allowed to witness executions in the USA, and because there are often more applications than places available, a macabre lottery is held to decide who gets chosen.
Oklahoma has cut the number of media seats from 12 to five.
Whoever is selected will watch it without emotion.
I can not do that.
I will be sitting next to Richard Glossip's closest friend, with whom I have developed my own relationship over the months with phone calls and a two and half hour visit.
I like the guy.
We often laugh a lot when we speak.
Prison authorities say I cannot be both a witness and a journalist, so I will not be allowed to take a notebook and pen to record what I see.
I just need to try to remember all the details.
A journalist from Oklahoma accused me on Twitter of giving up my impartiality.
Here is the lesson.
Tell the prisoner's story the way he wants it, and you'll get access.
I complained to her.
She admitted she "could have phrased it better", but she still thinks what I am doing is wrong.
Richard Glossip had a problem with some of the things I said and wrote.
He does not tell me what to write and I wouldn't do it even if he did.
I told him that he can remove me from his list of witnesses at any time.
But he wants an international reporter to be present to write about it.
When he dies, he thinks that the publicity generated by the anti-death penalty movement will help.
Kim Bellware, a reporter from the Huffington Post, will be sitting next to me.
If you want to know more about the case, please listen to the podcast series I have made.
I do not want to go into all the details again.
I can not say with certainty that Richard Glossip is innocent.
His actions after the murder of Barry Van Treese would make him guilty of being an accomplice to the crime.
But I believe there is a strong probability that he is not guilty of murder.
I certainly believe there is not enough evidence to justify a death sentence.
I believe that his execution is wrong.
And from that perspective, I will see him die.
I can't claim to be truly objective.
There will be other reporters that you can turn to for that.
What you will get from me is what it's like to see a man die an unnecessary death.
Man after wet police chase persuaded to come out of the Canning River

You know that it went on.

Serbia with 200,000 dollar bail after drug charge

He has clear ties to Serbia.

He admitted that the searches were done on his computer but said that it was done because he wanted to claim to be a police officer to scare paedophiles.

Berlin Tegel Prison: Five square metres of cell is inhumane.
The Federal Constitutional Court has ruled in favour of a former prisoner at Tegel Prison who was held in a cell that was too small for several months.
Prisoners are generally entitled to compensation for the violation of their human dignity if they are accommodated in cells that are too small.
The Federal Constitutional Court decided this in a decision published on Wednesday.
Even those held in the cramped conditions for just a few days should be entitled to compensation, judges said (ref. 1 BvR 1127/14).

A former prisoner has been successful with his constitutional complaint in Karlsruhe: he was accommodated in a single cell in the Berlin-Tegel penal institution between June and November 2009, with a floor area of about five square metres; the toilet was not separated from the rest of the room.
According to his lawyer, the man, who is now out of jail, was then put in a larger cell.
His action for damages against the city of Berlin on account of the inhumane conditions at the prison was unsuccessful.
But the constitutional judges overturned the Berlin court of appeal's ruling and sent the case back for further consideration.
They see the man's human dignity violated.
Supreme Court will now decide on the amount of the compensation
Although only a few days of detention could be taken into account for compensation purposes for legal reasons, a claim for compensation was justified, the court said.
Otherwise, there would be "a threat to the right to personality protection".
It is now up to the court of appeal to decide the exact amount of compensation.
In the past, the judges have often strengthened the rights of convicts.
In April they awarded damages to a prisoner who was locked naked in a cell.
According to a 2011 ruling, the multiple occupancy of a cell without a separate toilet is also inhumane.
Karlsruhe also confirmed that the Berlin Constitutional Court had ruled in a similar case in November 2009 that housing a prisoner in such conditions was inhuman.
The plaintiff in question was housed for over three months in a cell similar to the one in Karlsruhe for between 15 and 21 hours a day.
Berlin's prisons have been in the headlines in recent weeks because of a lack of staff.
Inmates are therefore often locked up for 23 hours a day, aggression is increasing, and there are even reports of fights breaking out because of the tense situation.
According to the justice press office, 21 positions are vacant in Tegel due to a lack of younger staff, 19 of them are to be cut in 2016.
Angela Merkel and refugee policy: "We can do it"
The immigration of refugees is an enormous challenge - the Chancellor is determined to accept it.
What is going to happen in Germany?

According to forecasts by the federal interior ministry, around 800,000 asylum seekers will come to Germany this year. According to Vice Chancellor Sigmar Gabriel (SPD), Germany is even able to accommodate one million refugees.
Chancellor Angela Merkel has demonstrated determination in the face of the unusual challenge: "Again and again I say: We can do this and we will do it."
The following overview provides a glimpse into what is coming for Germany.
According to different estimates, between 350,000 (Federal Ministry of Construction) and 400,000 (Pestel Institute) apartments will be needed each year for the next five years.
This is almost double the number currently being built (250,000 homes).

But the shortage of housing is especially dramatic when it comes to affordable rental properties: 60,000 to 80,000 social housing units fall out of rent control every year, and refugees will also apply for these particularly cheap apartments.
For this reason, Federal Minister of Construction Barbara Hendricks (SPD) will double the funding, from the current 518 million euros to 1 billion euros.
That's far too little in the view of the Pestel Institute: 80,000 social housing units should be built annually, for which the federal government would have to invest 4.6 billion euros a year.
Scientists and the federal building minister agree that there must be more tax benefits for investments in housing construction.
According to the Institute for Employment Research, it is estimated that in the long term, 55 percent of the refugees in Germany will be able to be employed.

However, refugees in Germany are not systematically asked about their qualifications to help them get started, criticises Claudia Walter, project manager for integration and education at the Bertelsmann Foundation.
The integration of refugees is crucial to whether they find work in Germany.
Work is the key to social contact, to recognition in the host society, but also to the self-esteem of migrants, migration researcher Dietrich Thränhardt says.
In Germany, according to Thränhardt, there has been a political turnaround: from a ban on working for refugees to the recognition of work.

While there used to be a five-year ban on asylum seekers working, this was reduced to three months in November 2014, as was a residence requirement which restricted asylum seekers to one place of residence.
Within society, there is a majority view that refugees should be given access to the labour market more quickly, partly due to a lack of skilled workers.
A major hurdle for access to the labour market is the lack of German language skills.
So far, there is no adequate provision of general and vocational language courses.
Studies also show that jobs are most often obtained through personal contacts.
Therefore, in the opinion of Thränhardt, the establishment of networks is the royal road to working integration.

The Berlin School Administration has found that only a few refugee parents are giving their kids to the daycare facilities, estimated to be 10 to 15 percent: "For uprooted parents, it is first of all very important to keep the family together," says Ilja Koschembar, spokesperson for youth and family in the Berlin State Administration.
To convince the family of the benefits of the daycare center, the administration distributes leaflets in different languages.

Should the need for childcare workers rise sharply due to the large number of refugees, the Berlin Senate will attempt to increase training capacities - for example, by allowing more vocational schools.
In the countries students without German language skills are prepared for lessons in welcome classes.
But they are not always taught by fully qualified teachers, but, as in Berlin, by teachers who only have a qualification in German as a second language.
There is no shortage of them, says Beate Stoffers from the Berlin School Administration.

Hammer artist spent three years on personal interpretation of the bible
Jesus with the (gilded) crown of thorns is one of the main works Otmar Alt has painted for his Bible.
Klaus Altepost has written the introduction and updated the Bible texts.
In the beginning was the word?
No, not the Otmar Alt bible, which has now appeared with magnificent pictures.
The image was the starting point for Otmar Alt, who has expressed his very personal interpretation of biblical stories in 150 motifs on paper and canvas.
His "language" of bold colours and imaginative shapes remains intact - but that does not mean his pictures are "funny".
On the contrary, depending on the themes in question, it can be quite dark.
Otmar Alt worked on his Bible project for about three years, for which he made a subjective-artistic selection from the many topics of the "book of all books".
Cycles were created that deal with themes such as the Stations of the Cross, plagues, commandments and the Lord's Prayer.
This has impressed several partners: both the Luther publishing house with its theological focus and the Kettler publishing house with its focus on art books.
Among them is author Klaus Altepost, who has delved into the Bible passages in each painting.
He interpreted the Bible passages selected by Otmar Alt and thus translated them into the present, into current contexts.
These texts are like verbal mirrors of Alt's paintings.
They are embedded between the original Bible quote by Martin Luther and a sentence by the artist, who here expresses his very personal thoughts on the respective situation.
The cover has golden letters.
So the 75-year-old allows a deep insight into his soul and his emotions.
This is a high level of intimacy.
Emotions were ultimately the trigger for the Bible project: Otmar Alt, born in 1940 in Wernigerode and raised in Berlin, comes from a family that belonged to the strict Protestant Herrnhut order.
"The education was sometimes done with the cane," remembers Otmar Alt.
"I've tried to work through this with the hope that I can reconcile with my father."
His second concern is to return art to a more prominent place in our fast-paced world: "The perception of image worlds today is dominated by advertising, and advertising is loud.
Symbolism will be pushed aside.
Artists have a different joy and pleasure in showing things.
Pictures always have something mysterious and are not decorative.
"In that sense, I am a dinosaur."
Otmar Alt wants the viewers to "fall into" the pictures, to let them have an effect on them, to discover and to feel what power they have: "The picture looks for its counterpart."

Klaus Altepost admitted on Tuesday, on the occasion of the presentation of the Otmar Alt Bible in the Otmar Alt Foundation, that he had "always" been a lover of Otmar Alt's art: "I like how he understands life with his pictures".
Alt had not paid attention to capture the Bible completely, but selected important and also mysterious topics for him.
"It was not a collaboration on an equal basis," says Altepost: "The images are the main focus, the text merely provides an explanation." The result was a picture Bible.
For Hans Möhler from Luther Verlag, this work is an invitation to "deepen life and find freedom".
Otmar Alt's pictures speak to Möhler both the (biblical) language of love and that of responsibility.
Some of the originals - paper and canvas - will be presented for the first time in an exhibition opening on November 15 at the Otmar Alt Foundation.

Self-driving cars: Government wants to take the lead for Germany
Germany should be a technological leader for the transformation in the automobile industry, according to the German federal government.

On Wednesday, the federal cabinet decided on a strategy paper from the House of Transport Minister Alexander Dobrindt (CSU), which among other things, will provide investment in the expansion of digital infrastructure.
Dobrindt spoke at the IAA car show in Frankfurt on Wednesday about a "new age of mobility."
Automated and interconnected driving will increase road safety and reduce traffic jams, Dobrindt said.
He also wants to discuss the topic with his colleagues from the G7 countries, who will also be meeting with industry representatives at the IAA.
The transport ministry's strategy paper highlights the importance of mobile broadband expansion and a rapid transition to digital radio.
A test track for testing new technology is currently being built on the A9 motorway in Bavaria.
In order to avoid "supplementary liability risks" for the driver, the federal government wants to "review the legal framework and adapt it, if necessary, to the new developments".
Germany, for example, wants to push internationally to raise the maximum speed for self-driving cars from 10 to 130km/h.
The government also wants to push for a change in the Vienna Convention that currently only allows people to drive a car.
In automated driving, the vehicle is increasingly taking the lead and the driver is becoming more and more of a passenger.
The technology relies on sensors and cameras that scan the surroundings and process the data within a second.
According to a study presented by the Ministry of Economic Affairs, highly automated driving on highways will be technically possible by 2020.
Nevertheless, driverless cars on public roads are "not expected until well after 2020".
According to the study, the value added in the area of driver assistance systems and highly automated driving functions in Germany is expected to be around 8.4 billion euros by 2025.
"Digital networking in cars can lead to more safety and efficiency in road traffic," said SPD transport politician Sören Bartol.
The question of liability in the case of accidents and the security of the drivers' personal data must also be clarified.
However, Germans are still more sceptical about self-driving cars than the French or the Americans.

According to a Forsa poll commissioned by German car safety organisation Dekra, only eight percent of Germans believe that self-driving cars will become a reality in the next ten years, while 32 percent believe it won't be until 20 years and 31 percent don't believe it will ever happen.
In France, 21 percent of respondents expect autonomous cars by 2025, in the US 33 percent.
In any case, car drivers in Germany are not yet ready to completely rely on a self-driving vehicle.
According to a survey by the digital association Bitkom, only 7% would agree to hand over control throughout the entire journey on all roads.
On the highway, 15 percent at least could imagine it in the flow of traffic, 45 percent in a traffic jam.
Nearly a quarter of people would not hand over control of their car under any circumstances.

EU to double mercury limit in predatory fishes
The European Commission wants to double the limit for mercury in large predatory fish, exposing consumers to a significantly higher dose of the neurotoxin.

Consumer group Foodwatch, which has a copy of the EU paper, has criticised the plan. "Risks and side-effects of misguided industrial and environmental policy are being passed on with full force to pregnant women and infants," said Matthias Wolfschmidt of Foodwatch.

Wolfschmidt said that the limits for mercury in big fish at the top of the food chain - such as shark and swordfish - should be raised from one to two milligrams of mercury per kilogram of fish for "economic reasons".
However, large predatory fish are already so heavily contaminated with mercury that around 50 percent of catches cannot be sold on the basis of the current limits.
After doubling the limits, only 14.5 percent would be unsellable.
In return for this relaxation, the EU wants to toughen the limits on mercury in other fish from 0.5 milligrams to 0.1 milligrams per kilogram, according to Foodwatch.
But Foodwatch described this as a "trick" because smaller fish such as carp are often so low in pollutants that they already meet the planned maximum values.
The reduction in small fish was "a perfidious diversion that only helps the economy," Wolfschmidt said.
Mercury is a highly toxic heavy metal which can accumulate in predatory fish via the food chain.
The government warns that "even small amounts can cause damage to the nervous system, particularly in unborn children"
However, the Federal Environment Ministry explains on its website with regard to the existing maximum values that "no health risk to the general population" could be expected.
Mercury is released into the environment mostly through coal burning.

Coal-fired power stations in Germany emit more than six tonnes of mercury each year, or around two-thirds of the total amount emitted in Germany, according to a written reply from the Federal Environment Ministry to Green party MP Annalena Baerbock.
Concentrations of mercury in fish, such as in the Rhine, Elbe and Danube rivers, are "permanently and widely exceeded," Der Spiegel quoted the paper in March.
Last year, European-wide warnings about mercury in fish were among the most frequently reported health risks in the EU's Rapid Alert System for Food and Feed (RASFF).
Foodwatch is calling on consumers to protest against the EU plans at www.quecksilber-aktion.foodwatch.de
